scenario: A controversial 'carnivore' diet forum is full of people claiming it cured their autoimmune issues (X). A doctor points out that people who felt worse on the diet likely left the forum (Z).
claim: The carnivore diet cures autoimmune issues for most people.
label: NO
causal_structure: Only responders stay on the diet
key_insight: You don't see the people who got sick and quit.
hidden_timestamp: The forum has no mechanism to track dropouts.

conditional_answers.condition_a: If the forum requires participants to register before starting and tracks dropouts, the data is valid. If it is voluntary posting, it is biased.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If the forum requires participants to register before starting and tracks dropouts, the data is valid. If it is voluntary posting, it is biased.

wise_refusal: The forum suffers from Selection Bias (Attrition Bias). We only observe those who tolerated the diet well (X). Those who suffered adverse effects (Z) left the community and are not in the dataset.
gold_rationale: Causal structure: Only responders stay on the diet Key insight: You don't see the people who got sick and quit. Explanation: The forum suffers from Selection Bias (Attrition Bias). We only observe those who tolerated the diet well (X). Those who suffered adverse effects (Z) left the community and are not in the dataset.

scenario: A free agent hits 50 home runs (X) in his contract year. The team signs him to a massive 10-year deal (I). Next year he hits 30 (Y). The GM is blamed for 'ruining' him.
claim: The General Manager's contract offer caused the player's performance decline.
label: NO
causal_structure: Contract signed at Peak X -> Y (Regression)
key_insight: Never pay for last year's stats.
hidden_timestamp: The contract was signed immediately following the outlier season.

conditional_answers.condition_a: If the player demonstrated a sustainable change in launch angle and exit velocity, the decline might be failure. If 50 HR was just a variance spike, Y is expected.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If the player demonstrated a sustainable change in launch angle and exit velocity, the decline might be failure. If 50 HR was just a variance spike, Y is expected.

wise_refusal: The 50 HR season (X) was an outlier performance (Career Year). Signing him (I) at the peak guarantees he will produce less (Y) simply due to Regression to the Mean (Extreme-Group Selection). The contract didn't ruin him; statistics did.
gold_rationale: Causal structure: Contract signed at Peak X -> Y (Regression) Key insight: Never pay for last year's stats. Explanation: The 50 HR season (X) was an outlier performance (Career Year). Signing him (I) at the peak guarantees he will produce less (Y) simply due to Regression to the Mean (Extreme-Group Selection). The contract didn't ruin him; statistics did.

scenario: A driver is 20 seconds behind (X). The strategist keeps him out on old tires hoping for a Safety Car. A Safety Car happens (Z), closing the gap and allowing a cheap pit stop. Driver wins (Y). The strategist is hailed as a genius.
claim: The strategy to stay out on old tires was the correct decision based on information available at the time.
label: NO
causal_structure: Bad strategy X + Luck Z -> Good Outcome Y
key_insight: Strategies that rely on 5% probability events are usually bad, even if they work.
hidden_timestamp: The probability of a Safety Car was 15%.

conditional_answers.condition_a: If the team had weather data or track data suggesting a Safety Car was highly probable (>40%), the strategy was sound. If they relied on a 15% chance, it was a lucky gamble.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If the team had weather data or track data suggesting a Safety Car was highly probable (>40%), the strategy was sound. If they relied on a 15% chance, it was a lucky gamble.

wise_refusal: This is Selection Bias (Sampling-on-the-Outcome). The strategy (X) had a low expected value and relied on a lucky event (Z). Validating the process based on the lucky result (Y) reinforces bad decision-making.
gold_rationale: Causal structure: Bad strategy X + Luck Z -> Good Outcome Y Key insight: Strategies that rely on 5% probability events are usually bad, even if they work. Explanation: This is Selection Bias (Sampling-on-the-Outcome). The strategy (X) had a low expected value and relied on a lucky event (Z). Validating the process based on the lucky result (Y) reinforces bad decision-making.

scenario: A study shows that pitchers who consistently throw over 100mph in the majors (X) rarely have elbow surgery (Y). A coach encourages youth pitchers to throw max effort to protect their elbows.
claim: Throwing max effort protects youth pitchers' elbows.
label: NO
causal_structure: X (100mph) -> Y (Health) in survivors only
key_insight: Survivorship Bias hides the injuries.
hidden_timestamp: Pitchers who blow out their elbows don't make the majors.

conditional_answers.condition_a: If youth pitchers have the same elite connective tissue as the MLB survivors, X applies. If not, high velocity increases injury risk.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If youth pitchers have the same elite connective tissue as the MLB survivors, X applies. If not, high velocity increases injury risk.

wise_refusal: This is Survivorship Bias (Historical Filtering). Pitchers who threw 100mph and blew out their elbows (Z) are not in the 'majors' dataset. Only the genetic outliers who could withstand the stress (X) remained. Mimicking them will likely injure normal arms.
gold_rationale: Causal structure: X (100mph) -> Y (Health) in survivors only Key insight: Survivorship Bias hides the injuries. Explanation: This is Survivorship Bias (Historical Filtering). Pitchers who threw 100mph and blew out their elbows (Z) are not in the 'majors' dataset. Only the genetic outliers who could withstand the stress (X) remained. Mimicking them will likely injure normal arms.

scenario: A golfer is putting terribly (X) and switches to a new brand of putter (I). His putting improves in the next tournament (Y). He claims the new putter is the cause.
claim: The new putter caused the improvement in putting performance.
label: NO
causal_structure: Switching putter at nadir
key_insight: You change the putter when you can't putt.
hidden_timestamp: The switch happened after the worst round of the year.

conditional_answers.condition_a: If the old putter was physically damaged or ill-fitted, the switch (I) caused Y. If the old putter was fine, Z (regression) caused Y.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If the old putter was physically damaged or ill-fitted, the switch (I) caused Y. If the old putter was fine, Z (regression) caused Y.

wise_refusal: Golfers switch putters (I) when their performance is at a trough (X). Improvement (Y) is expected due to Regression to the Mean (Extreme-Group Selection), regardless of the equipment change.
gold_rationale: Causal structure: Switching putter at nadir Key insight: You change the putter when you can't putt. Explanation: Golfers switch putters (I) when their performance is at a trough (X). Improvement (Y) is expected due to Regression to the Mean (Extreme-Group Selection), regardless of the equipment change.

scenario: A strict coach uses harsh, abusive training methods (X). His gym produces several Olympic medalists (Y). Parents argue his methods are necessary for success.
claim: Abusive training methods are necessary to produce Olympic medalists.
label: NO
causal_structure: Abusive training X selects for survivors Y
key_insight: Harsh methods break the weak; only the strong remain.
hidden_timestamp: 90% of students quit or get injured.

conditional_answers.condition_a: If the training method teaches specific technical skills achievable no other way, X causes Y. If it simply filters for durability, it is survivorship.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If the training method teaches specific technical skills achievable no other way, X causes Y. If it simply filters for durability, it is survivorship.

wise_refusal: This is Survivorship Bias (Selective Observation). The harsh methods (X) filter out everyone except the most resilient genetic outliers (Y). The many athletes broken by the system (Z) are ignored. Success might be despite the training, not because of it.
gold_rationale: Causal structure: Abusive training X selects for survivors Y Key insight: Harsh methods break the weak; only the strong remain. Explanation: This is Survivorship Bias (Selective Observation). The harsh methods (X) filter out everyone except the most resilient genetic outliers (Y). The many athletes broken by the system (Z) are ignored. Success might be despite the training, not because of it.

scenario: A player appears on the cover of a video game (X) after an MVP season. Next season he is plagued by minor injuries and stats drop (Y). Fans claim he is cursed.
claim: Appearing on the video game cover caused the performance decline.
label: NO
causal_structure: Cover selection at Peak -> Regression
key_insight: Being on the cover requires being an outlier.
hidden_timestamp: Selection for cover requires peak performance.

conditional_answers.condition_a: If the player was concealing an injury at the time of selection, X predicts Y. Otherwise, it is standard regression.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If the player was concealing an injury at the time of selection, X predicts Y. Otherwise, it is standard regression.

wise_refusal: The 'Curse' is Regression to the Mean (Extreme-Group Selection). Only players with outlier seasons (X) are selected for covers. Outlier seasons usually involve good health luck, which normalizes (Y) in subsequent years.
gold_rationale: Causal structure: Cover selection at Peak -> Regression Key insight: Being on the cover requires being an outlier. Explanation: The 'Curse' is Regression to the Mean (Extreme-Group Selection). Only players with outlier seasons (X) are selected for covers. Outlier seasons usually involve good health luck, which normalizes (Y) in subsequent years.

scenario: A study on a new high-intensity workout recruits volunteers (X). The participants show massive fitness gains (Y). The gym markets the workout to the general public.
claim: The workout program will produce massive fitness gains for the general public.
label: NO
causal_structure: Volunteers for study X differ from population
key_insight: Lazy people don't volunteer for exercise studies.
hidden_timestamp: The study required 6am attendance.

conditional_answers.condition_a: If the workout is tested on a random sample of the population, results might hold. With volunteers, motivation confounds the result.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If the workout is tested on a random sample of the population, results might hold. With volunteers, motivation confounds the result.

wise_refusal: The study suffers from Selection Bias (Conditioning on Participation). Volunteers (X) are inherently more motivated and disciplined than the general public (Z). The efficacy of the workout is confounded by the participants' drive.
gold_rationale: Causal structure: Volunteers for study X differ from population Key insight: Lazy people don't volunteer for exercise studies. Explanation: The study suffers from Selection Bias (Conditioning on Participation). Volunteers (X) are inherently more motivated and disciplined than the general public (Z). The efficacy of the workout is confounded by the participants' drive.

scenario: A GM drafts a highly touted QB (X). In his rookie season, he posts average stats (Y). Fans label him a 'bust'. The GM argues that given he had the worst offensive line in the league (Z), average performance is actually promising.
claim: The quarterback is a 'bust' lacking the necessary skill for the NFL.
label: NO
causal_structure: Context Z explains Outcome Y
key_insight: Stats don't tell the whole story for rookies.
hidden_timestamp: QB was sacked 60 times.

conditional_answers.condition_a: If the QB held the ball too long causing the sacks, Y is on him. If the pressure was instantaneous, Y is a team failure, not a player bust.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If the QB held the ball too long causing the sacks, Y is on him. If the pressure was instantaneous, Y is a team failure, not a player bust.

wise_refusal: This is Confounding (Omitted Variable). Judging the QB solely on raw stats (Y) ignores the confounding variable of the offensive line (Z). Producing 'average' stats under 'terrible' conditions often indicates above-average skill.
gold_rationale: Causal structure: Context Z explains Outcome Y Key insight: Stats don't tell the whole story for rookies. Explanation: This is Confounding (Omitted Variable). Judging the QB solely on raw stats (Y) ignores the confounding variable of the offensive line (Z). Producing 'average' stats under 'terrible' conditions often indicates above-average skill.

scenario: A team loses 4 games in a row (X). The captain holds a 'players only' meeting (I) to scream at everyone. They win the next game (Y). The captain credits the meeting.
claim: The team meeting caused the win in the next game.
label: NO
causal_structure: Meeting called at losing streak trough
key_insight: Yelling at players works because they were going to win anyway.
hidden_timestamp: Meetings only happen when things are bad.

conditional_answers.condition_a: If tactical changes were made during the meeting, I caused Y. If it was just emotional yelling, regression (Z) likely explains Y.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If tactical changes were made during the meeting, I caused Y. If it was just emotional yelling, regression (Z) likely explains Y.

wise_refusal: The meeting (I) was triggered by the losing streak (X). Since sports performance fluctuates, the team was statistically likely to win the next game (Y) anyway due to Regression to the Mean (Extreme-Group Selection).
gold_rationale: Causal structure: Meeting called at losing streak trough Key insight: Yelling at players works because they were going to win anyway. Explanation: The meeting (I) was triggered by the losing streak (X). Since sports performance fluctuates, the team was statistically likely to win the next game (Y) anyway due to Regression to the Mean (Extreme-Group Selection).

scenario: A player skips college to go pro (X) citing Kobe Bryant and LeBron James as proof it works. His guidance counselor advises against it.
claim: Skipping college is a reliable path to NBA stardom for high school players.
label: NO
causal_structure: Successful dropouts X visible; failed dropouts Z invisible
key_insight: Kobe made it. Your neighbor didn't.
hidden_timestamp: Dataset includes only NBA All-Stars.

conditional_answers.condition_a: If the player has physical metrics comparable to Kobe/LeBron, X might work. If average, Z applies.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If the player has physical metrics comparable to Kobe/LeBron, X might work. If average, Z applies.

wise_refusal: The player is relying on Survivorship Bias (Historical Filtering). He sees the superstars who succeeded (X) but ignores the many high schoolers who skipped college, failed to make the NBA, and are currently unemployed (Z).
gold_rationale: Causal structure: Successful dropouts X visible; failed dropouts Z invisible Key insight: Kobe made it. Your neighbor didn't. Explanation: The player is relying on Survivorship Bias (Historical Filtering). He sees the superstars who succeeded (X) but ignores the many high schoolers who skipped college, failed to make the NBA, and are currently unemployed (Z).

scenario: A coach notices that when he praises a player for a great play (X), the player does worse next time. When he yells at a player for a bad play (X'), the player does better. He concludes punishment is better than praise.
claim: Punishment is more effective than praise for improving performance.
label: NO
causal_structure: Punish after bad (X) -> Better (Y); Reward after good (X') -> Worse (Y')
key_insight: Kahneman's flight instructor example.
hidden_timestamp: Performance oscillates around a mean.

conditional_answers.condition_a: If the player wasn't trying, punishment might work. If they were trying their best, regression explains the fluctuation.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If the player wasn't trying, punishment might work. If they were trying their best, regression explains the fluctuation.

wise_refusal: This is the classic Regression to the Mean (Extreme-Group Selection) trap. A great play (X) is likely followed by a worse one, and a bad play (X') by a better one, regardless of the coach's feedback. The coach is mistaking statistical regression for the effect of his intervention.
gold_rationale: Causal structure: Punish after bad (X) -> Better (Y); Reward after good (X') -> Worse (Y') Key insight: Kahneman's flight instructor example. Explanation: This is the classic Regression to the Mean (Extreme-Group Selection) trap. A great play (X) is likely followed by a worse one, and a bad play (X') by a better one, regardless of the coach's feedback. The coach is mistaking statistical regression for the effect of his intervention.

scenario: Data shows that riders on $10,000 bikes (X) average 5mph faster speeds than riders on $500 bikes (Y). A beginner buys a $10,000 bike expecting to ride 5mph faster.
claim: Buying a $10,000 bike will make a beginner ride 5mph faster.
label: NO
causal_structure: Rich/Serious people buy expensive bikes X
key_insight: It's the rider, not the bike.
hidden_timestamp: Only fit, serious cyclists invest in X.

conditional_answers.condition_a: If the beginner is already at elite fitness, X helps. If not, Z (fitness) dominates.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If the beginner is already at elite fitness, X helps. If not, Z (fitness) dominates.

wise_refusal: This is Confounding (Confounding by Indication). The group owning $10,000 bikes (X) consists of serious, fit cyclists. The bike contributes marginally, but the speed difference is primarily caused by the rider's fitness (Z).
gold_rationale: Causal structure: Rich/Serious people buy expensive bikes X Key insight: It's the rider, not the bike. Explanation: This is Confounding (Confounding by Indication). The group owning $10,000 bikes (X) consists of serious, fit cyclists. The bike contributes marginally, but the speed difference is primarily caused by the rider's fitness (Z).

scenario: A player wins 'Most Improved Player' (X). The next season, his stats decline slightly (Y). Analysts say he 'rested on his laurels'.
claim: The player's decline was caused by resting on his laurels.
label: NO
causal_structure: Award selected on positive delta X -> Y Regression
key_insight: Improvement is rarely linear.
hidden_timestamp: The award captures the steepest ascent.

conditional_answers.condition_a: If the player is young and developing skills, the improvement might be sticky. If it was just a hot shooting year, regression occurs.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If the player is young and developing skills, the improvement might be sticky. If it was just a hot shooting year, regression occurs.

wise_refusal: The 'Most Improved' award selects for a season where everything went right (X). It is statistically probable that the player will not sustain that rate of growth and will regress toward a more stable mean (Y) next season due to Regression to the Mean (Extreme-Group Selection).
gold_rationale: Causal structure: Award selected on positive delta X -> Y Regression Key insight: Improvement is rarely linear. Explanation: The 'Most Improved' award selects for a season where everything went right (X). It is statistically probable that the player will not sustain that rate of growth and will regress toward a more stable mean (Y) next season due to Regression to the Mean (Extreme-Group Selection).

scenario: The league introduces better helmets (X) to reduce concussions. The concussion rate does not drop (Y). Observers blame the helmet design.
claim: Better helmets will reduce the concussion rate.
label: NO
causal_structure: Intervention X leads to riskier behavior Z -> Outcome Y
key_insight: Peltzman Effect / Risk Compensation.
hidden_timestamp: Players feel safer.

conditional_answers.condition_a: If player behavior (Z) remains constant, Y should drop. If risk compensation occurs, Y stays constant.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If player behavior (Z) remains constant, Y should drop. If risk compensation occurs, Y stays constant.

wise_refusal: This is Goodhart's Law (Policy Response Loop) or Risk Compensation. Feeling safer due to better helmets (X), players may have adopted more dangerous tackling techniques (Z), offsetting the safety benefits.
gold_rationale: Causal structure: Intervention X leads to riskier behavior Z -> Outcome Y Key insight: Peltzman Effect / Risk Compensation. Explanation: This is Goodhart's Law (Policy Response Loop) or Risk Compensation. Feeling safer due to better helmets (X), players may have adopted more dangerous tackling techniques (Z), offsetting the safety benefits.

scenario: An analysis of NBA players shows that shorter players (X) have higher free throw percentages than taller players. A coach concludes that being short causes better shooting.
claim: Being short causes a player to have better shooting skill.
label: NO
causal_structure: Collider bias on 'Being in NBA'
key_insight: Short players in the NBA are insanely skilled.
hidden_timestamp: Selection into the NBA requires either Height OR Skill.

conditional_answers.condition_a: If short stature mechanistically aids shooting form, X causes Y. If it's a collider, Z causes the correlation.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If short stature mechanistically aids shooting form, X causes Y. If it's a collider, Z causes the correlation.

wise_refusal: This is Selection Bias (Conditioning on Participation), specifically Berkson's Paradox. To make the NBA (Z), you need to be either very tall OR very skilled. Short players in the NBA (X) must be exceptionally skilled (Y) to have made the cut, creating a negative correlation between height and skill within the selected sample.
gold_rationale: Causal structure: Collider bias on 'Being in NBA' Key insight: Short players in the NBA are insanely skilled. Explanation: This is Selection Bias (Conditioning on Participation), specifically Berkson's Paradox. To make the NBA (Z), you need to be either very tall OR very skilled. Short players in the NBA (X) must be exceptionally skilled (Y) to have made the cut, creating a negative correlation between height and skill within the selected sample.

scenario: A striker scores 8 goals in 5 games (X). In the next 5 games, he scores 0 (Y). Fans claim he has 'lost his confidence'.
claim: The striker's scoreless streak is caused by a loss of confidence.
label: NO
causal_structure: Extreme success X -> Regression Y
key_insight: Streaks end.
hidden_timestamp: Sustain rate of 1.6 goals/game is impossible.

conditional_answers.condition_a: If he stopped taking shots, it's confidence. If he kept shooting but missed, it's likely variance/regression.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If he stopped taking shots, it's confidence. If he kept shooting but missed, it's likely variance/regression.

wise_refusal: Regression to the Mean (Noise-Induced Extremes). 8 goals in 5 games (X) is unsustainable (outlier). Scoring 0 in the next 5 (Y) is a variation that brings his average back to a normal rate. It's variance, not psychology.
gold_rationale: Causal structure: Extreme success X -> Regression Y Key insight: Streaks end. Explanation: Regression to the Mean (Noise-Induced Extremes). 8 goals in 5 games (X) is unsustainable (outlier). Scoring 0 in the next 5 (Y) is a variation that brings his average back to a normal rate. It's variance, not psychology.

scenario: A 1920s baseball star smoked cigars and ate hot dogs (X) yet played until 40. A modern player adopts this diet to improve longevity.

label: NO

conditional_answers.condition_b: If the modern player shares the specific genetic mutations (Z) of the star, it might work. If not, X is harmful.

wise_refusal: Survivorship Bias (Historical Filtering). The 1920s star (Y) had such elite genetics (Z) that he succeeded despite the bad diet (X). Lesser athletes with that diet failed and were forgotten.
gold_rationale: Causal structure: Unhealthy habits X only visible in superstars Y Key insight: If you smoke and play, you must be Babe Ruth. Explanation: Survivorship Bias (Historical Filtering). The 1920s star (Y) had such elite genetics (Z) that he succeeded despite the bad diet (X). Lesser athletes with that diet failed and were forgotten.

conditional_answers.condition_a: If the streak was due to weak opponents, Y is regression. If it was a tactical breakthrough, the streak might continue.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If the streak was due to weak opponents, Y is regression. If it was a tactical breakthrough, the streak might continue.

wise_refusal: The 'Manager of the Month' award selects for a peak performance streak (X). It is statistically expected that the team will not sustain that win rate and will regress (Y) immediately after the award period due to Regression to the Mean (Extreme-Group Selection).
gold_rationale: Causal structure: Award X given at peak -> Y Regression Key insight: The curse of the Manager of the Month. scenario: A scout notices that 40% of NHL starters (elite players) are born in January-March (X). He decides to only draft players born in those months, believing they are genetically superior.
claim: Drafting players born in Jan-Mar ensures genetic superiority.
label: NO

key_insight: Relative Age Effect.
hidden_timestamp: Youth hockey cutoff is Jan 1.

conditional_answers.condition_a: If the age cutoff changes, the bias shifts. If the cutoff remains Jan 1, the bias persists.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If the age cutoff changes, the bias shifts. If the cutoff remains Jan 1, the bias persists.

wise_refusal: This is Confounding (Confounding by Indication) caused by the Relative Age Effect. Players born in Q1 (X) were the oldest in their youth cohorts (Z), getting better coaching and selection. By draft age, the biological advantage is gone; selecting for it now is an error.
gold_rationale: Causal structure: Birth month affects selection X Key insight: Relative Age Effect. Explanation: This is Confounding (Confounding by Indication) caused by the Relative Age Effect. Players born in Q1 (X) were the oldest in their youth cohorts (Z), getting better coaching and selection. By draft age, the biological advantage is gone; selecting for it now is an error.

scenario: A quarterback throws a desperation 'Hail Mary' pass (X) into triple coverage and it is caught for a touchdown (Y). The coach designs more plays throwing into triple coverage.

conditional_answers.condition_b: If the receiver is 7ft tall and opponents are 5ft, X might work. Otherwise, it is a negative expected value play.

wise_refusal: Selection Bias (Sampling-on-the-Outcome). The success of the Hail Mary (Y) was a high-variance lucky event (Z). Throwing into triple coverage (X) is generally a negative Expected Value strategy.
gold_rationale: Causal structure: Low prob event X succeeds Y Key insight: Don't plan for miracles. Explanation: Selection Bias (Sampling-on-the-Outcome). The success of the Hail Mary (Y) was a high-variance lucky event (Z). Throwing into triple coverage (X) is generally a negative Expected Value strategy.

scenario: The batting champion hits .360 (X) this year. Next year he hits .320 (Y). Fans claim he is distracted by his new fame.

conditional_answers.condition_b: If his underlying exit velocity and contact rates dropped, X might be distraction. If his BABIP (luck) simply normalized, it is regression.

wise_refusal: Winning a batting title (X) usually requires career-best luck on balls in play. A drop to .320 (Y) is a natural Regression to the Mean (Extreme-Group Selection) to the player's true talent level, not evidence of distraction (Z).
gold_rationale: Causal structure: Top performer X declines Y Key insight: The batting champion rarely repeats. Explanation: Winning a batting title (X) usually requires career-best luck on balls in play. A drop to .320 (Y) is a natural Regression to the Mean (Extreme-Group Selection) to the player's true talent level, not evidence of distraction (Z).

label: NO

conditional_answers.condition_b: If looking fresh influences judges in close rounds, X causes Y. If X is purely a result of taking less damage, causality is reversed.

wise_refusal: Reverse Causation (Outcome-driven Selection). Fighters look fresh (X) because they dominated the fight and took less damage (Z), which is also why they won (Y). Faking freshness won't change the fight result.
gold_rationale: Causal structure: Winners look fresh X Key insight: Winning makes you less tired. Explanation: Reverse Causation (Outcome-driven Selection). Fighters look fresh (X) because they dominated the fight and took less damage (Z), which is also why they won (Y). Faking freshness won't change the fight result.

scenario: A defense forces 40 turnovers in a season (X), a league record. The next season, they force 20 (Y). The coordinator is fired for the decline.

label: NO
causal_structure: Turnovers are lucky.

hidden_timestamp: Turnovers have low year-to-year correlation.

conditional_answers.condition_a: If the scheme relied on specific players who left, the drop is causal. If personnel remained same, the drop is regression.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If the scheme relied on specific players who left, the drop is causal. If personnel remained same, the drop is regression.

conditional_answers.condition_a: If statistical analysis of all calls shows a decline in accuracy, Y is valid. If based only on viral clips (X), it is bias.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If statistical analysis of all calls shows a decline in accuracy, Y is valid. If based only on viral clips (X), it is bias.

wise_refusal: Survivorship Bias (Selective Observation). Social media selects and amplifies mistakes (X) while ignoring the thousands of correct calls (Z). High-definition replay also makes errors more visible than in the past, creating an illusion of decline (Y).
gold_rationale: Causal structure: We only notice bad calls X Key insight: Nobody tweets 'Nice call ref'. Explanation: Survivorship Bias (Selective Observation). Social media selects and amplifies mistakes (X) while ignoring the thousands of correct calls (Z). High-definition replay also makes errors more visible than in the past, creating an illusion of decline (Y).

scenario: A team wins a match 7-0 (X), scoring on every shot. The next week they play a 0-0 draw (Y). Fans joke 'they used up all their goals'.
claim: The team failed to score because they used up their goals in the previous game.
label: NO
causal_structure: Extreme performance X -> Regression Y
key_insight: Goals are not a finite resource, but variance is.
hidden_timestamp: XG in first game was only 2.5.

conditional_answers.condition_a: If the 7-0 was against a relegated team and the 0-0 against the champion, opponent strength explains Y. If opponents were equal, regression explains Y.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If the 7-0 was against a relegated team and the 0-0 against the champion, opponent strength explains Y. If opponents were equal, regression explains Y.

wise_refusal: Regression to the Mean (Noise-Induced Extremes). The 7-0 win (X) likely involved unsustainable finishing luck (scoring on every chance). The 0-0 draw (Y) represents a return to normal finishing variance, not a mystical depletion of a goal quota.
gold_rationale: Causal structure: Extreme performance X -> Regression Y Key insight: Goals are not a finite resource, but variance is. Explanation: Regression to the Mean (Noise-Induced Extremes). The 7-0 win (X) likely involved unsustainable finishing luck (scoring on every chance). The 0-0 draw (Y) represents a return to normal finishing variance, not a mystical depletion of a goal quota.

scenario: A coach teaches kids to swing at bad pitches because a Hall of Famer (X) was famous for hitting bad pitches.
claim: Teaching kids to swing at bad pitches will help them succeed.
label: NO
causal_structure: HoF players X had specific style
key_insight: Don't teach kids to swing like Vlad Guerrero.
hidden_timestamp: X had superhuman hand-eye coordination.

conditional_answers.condition_a: If the kids have the same elite hand-eye coordination as X, it works. If not, Z (failure) is the result.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If the kids have the same elite hand-eye coordination as X, it works. If not, Z (failure) is the result.

wise_refusal: Survivorship Bias (Historical Filtering). The Hall of Famer (X) succeeded *despite* his bad pitch selection due to freakish hand-eye coordination. Most players who swing at bad pitches (Z) strike out and do not make the Hall of Fame.
gold_rationale: Causal structure: HoF players X had specific style Key insight: Don't teach kids to swing like Vlad Guerrero. Explanation: Survivorship Bias (Historical Filtering). The Hall of Famer (X) succeeded *despite* his bad pitch selection due to freakish hand-eye coordination. Most players who swing at bad pitches (Z) strike out and do not make the Hall of Fame.

scenario: A player gets 20 sacks (X) but has a low pressure rate. Analysts predict he will regress next year. Fans call the analysts 'haters'. He gets 8 sacks next year (Y).
claim: The player will continue to get 20 sacks a year.
label: NO
causal_structure: Sack conversion rate X is unstable
key_insight: Sacks are rarer than pressures.
hidden_timestamp: Pressure rate predicts future sacks better than past sacks.

conditional_answers.condition_a: If the player improved his technique to win quickly, X might sustain. Since pressure rate (Z) was low, regression is expected.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If the player improved his technique to win quickly, X might sustain. Since pressure rate (Z) was low, regression is expected.

wise_refusal: Sack totals (X) are volatile and depend on finishing luck. Pressure rate (Z) is a more stable indicator of skill. The drop to 8 sacks (Y) is a predictable Regression to the Mean (Noise-Induced Extremes) because his underlying pressure metrics did not support the 20-sack outlier.
gold_rationale: Causal structure: Sack conversion rate X is unstable Key insight: Sacks are rarer than pressures. Explanation: Sack totals (X) are volatile and depend on finishing luck. Pressure rate (Z) is a more stable indicator of skill. The drop to 8 sacks (Y) is a predictable Regression to the Mean (Noise-Induced Extremes) because his underlying pressure metrics did not support the 20-sack outlier.

scenario: A basketball analyst observes that players who have higher average points per game in televised matches tend to receive more endorsement deals. The data is collected only from televised games and players who regularly start those games. Based on this, it appears that scoring more points causes an increase in endorsements. However, the dataset excludes bench players and those who rarely appear on televised matches.
claim: Increasing a player's average points per game in televised matches causes them to receive more endorsement deals.
label: NO

variables.X: Average points per game in televised matches
variables.Z: Player selection for televised games (starter status and frequency of playtime)

causal_structure: Z influences both X and Y, creating a selection bias where only starters with more playtime (Z) are included, who naturally score more (X) and attract more endorsements (Y). This selection mechanism obscures the true causal effect of X on Y.
key_insight: The observed association between scoring and endorsements is confounded by selective inclusion of players with more playtime in televised games, not a direct causal effect.
hidden_timestamp: Who is systematically excluded from the dataset: bench players and players with limited or no televised playtime?

conditional_answers.condition_a: If we find that bench players who score fewer points and rarely play in televised matches also receive fewer endorsements, then the causal claim might be more plausible because the selection mechanism is less influential.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If we find that some bench players or less televised players score highly but receive few endorsements, then the causal claim fails as endorsement deals depend on visibility and playtime, not just scoring.

wise_refusal: This claim falls into the T1: SELECTION trap because it only considers players who start and frequently play in televised games, excluding bench players and those with limited exposure. To resolve the causal ambiguity, we need information about those systematically excluded players and their scoring and endorsement outcomes. Without accounting for this selection bias, we cannot confidently assert that higher scoring causes more endorsements, as the observed association may be driven by visibility and playtime rather than scoring alone.
gold_rationale: The causal claim that increasing a player's scoring causes more endorsements is invalid due to selection bias: the dataset only includes players who start and often appear in televised games, excluding other players who may have different scoring and endorsement patterns. This selection mechanism (Z) affects both the exposure (X) and the outcome (Y), confounding the observed association. Without data on excluded players, it is impossible to disentangle whether scoring truly causes endorsements or whether visibility and playtime drive both. Hence, the hidden question about who is systematically excluded is critical to resolving the causal ambiguity and determining the validity of the causal claim.

scenario: A soccer analyst observes that teams who substitute their star striker during a match tend to concede fewer goals afterward. Based on match reports from top-level leagues, it seems like the intervention of substituting the star striker (X) causes a decrease in goals conceded (Y). However, the data only includes matches where the substitution was made, ignoring matches where no substitution occurred or where the star striker played full-time. Additionally, substitution decisions are influenced by the current match situation and player fitness, which are not recorded in the dataset.
claim: Substituting the star striker during a match causes a team to concede fewer goals.
label: NO

variables.X: Substitution of the star striker during the match
variables.Y: Number of goals conceded after substitution
variables.Z: Unrecorded match situation and player fitness influencing substitution decision

causal_structure: Z (match situation, player fitness) -> X (substitution decision) -> Y (goals conceded), but also Z directly influences Y; selection bias arises because only matches with substitution are observed.
key_insight: Who is systematically excluded? Matches without substitutions and their corresponding outcomesthis selection bias hides whether substitution truly causes fewer goals conceded or if it is confounded by the match situation.
hidden_timestamp: Which matches are excluded due to no substitutions? Are these systematically different in scorelines or player conditions?

conditional_answers.condition_a: If we find that excluded matches (no substitution) generally involve teams already leading comfortably and conceding fewer goals regardless, then the observed decrease in goals after substitution is confounded by match situation, invalidating the causal claim.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If we find that excluded matches involve teams trailing or with similar fitness issues but no substitution and they concede more goals, this supports the substitution having a genuine causal effect in reducing goals conceded.

wise_refusal: This claim falls into the T1: SELECTION trap because the dataset only captures matches where the substitution was made, systematically excluding matches without substitutions. To resolve the causal ambiguity, we need information on matches where no substitution occurred and the match situations leading to these decisions. Without this hidden information, we cannot determine if substituting the star striker truly causes fewer goals conceded or if the observed association is driven by the unobserved selection bias.
gold_rationale: The observed association between substituting the star striker and fewer goals conceded is confounded by selection bias: the data only includes matches with substitutions, ignoring those without. The hidden variable Z (match situation and player fitness) influences both the decision to substitute (X) and the outcome (Y), creating a spurious correlation. Without data on excluded matches, we cannot disentangle whether the substitution causally reduces goals conceded or if teams in favorable situations both are more likely to substitute and concede fewer goals. Hence, the causal claim is unjustified until the selection mechanism is fully revealed.

scenario: A tennis coach observes that players who undergo an intensive strength training program (X) tend to win more matches (Y) in a recent regional tournament. However, only players who qualified through rigorous local competitions were allowed to participate in this tournament. The coach does not have data on players who did not qualify or were excluded from the tournament.
claim: Intensive strength training directly causes better match outcomes in tennis players.
label: NO

variables.X: Participation in intensive strength training program
variables.Y: Winning matches in the regional tournament
variables.Z: Selection mechanism based on qualification through local competitions

causal_structure: X -> Y, but Z (selection based on qualification) influences both X and Y by restricting the pool of observed players, inducing selection bias.
key_insight: The observed positive association between strength training and match wins may be confounded by the selective inclusion of players who have already met certain performance thresholds (Z).
hidden_timestamp: Who is systematically excluded from the tournament and thus from the observed data?

conditional_answers.condition_a: If excluded players mostly did not undergo strength training and performed poorly, the observed effect might overestimate the true benefit of strength training.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If excluded players included both those with and without strength training and varied in performance, the observed association might be more representative and the causal claim more plausible.

wise_refusal: This scenario exemplifies the T1: SELECTION trap, where the dataset includes only players who qualified through local competitions, systematically excluding others. Without knowing who was excluded and why, we cannot ascertain whether the observed link between strength training and winning is causal or driven by selection bias. To resolve this ambiguity, we need information about the unobserved playerswho they are, their training status, and their performance. Without this, making a causal claim would be premature and potentially misleading.
gold_rationale: The key issue is that the data is conditioned on selection into the tournament (Z), which is influenced by prior performance and possibly by whether players engaged in strength training (X). This conditioning creates a non-representative sample, introducing selection bias that can produce a spurious association between X and Y. Recognizing this, the hidden question about who is excluded is critical to disambiguate whether strength training truly causes better outcomes or if the observed effect is an artifact of selection. Different assumptions about the excluded players lead to contrasting interpretations, underscoring the necessity of this information before confirming any causal claim.

scenario: A baseball analyst observes that players who have higher batting practice hours (X) tend to have higher batting averages during the season (Y). The data collected is only from players who made the team roster and played at least 30 games. Players who did not make the roster or were cut early are not included in the dataset.
claim: Increasing batting practice hours causally improves a player's batting average during the season.
label: NO

variables.Z: Selection into the team roster (players who played 30 games)

causal_structure: X  Y, but Z (selection into roster) acts as a collider that conditions the observed data set, inducing a selection bias that confounds the apparent causal relation between X and Y.
key_insight: Who is systematically excluded from the dataset (players not making the roster or playing fewer than 30 games)?
hidden_timestamp: The selection filter occurs after batting practice but before observing season batting average, conditioning on roster inclusion.

conditional_answers.condition_a: If excluded players tend to have low batting practice hours and very low batting averages, then the observed positive correlation between practice hours and batting average is inflated by selection bias.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If excluded players have a random distribution of batting practice hours and performance, then the observed correlation better reflects the true causal effect of batting practice on batting average.

wise_refusal: This claim is vulnerable to a T1: SELECTION trap because the data only includes players who made the roster and played significant games, excluding those who failed to make the team or played very little. To resolve the causal ambiguity, we need information about the players excluded by this selection criterionspecifically, their batting practice hours and potential batting averages had they played more. Without this, we cannot determine whether the observed correlation reflects a genuine causal effect or a biased sample selection effect. Therefore, it is not justified to conclude that increasing batting practice causally improves batting average based on the available data.
gold_rationale: The observed data conditions on a post-intervention selection variable (making the team roster and playing 30 games), which is itself influenced by both the exposure (batting practice hours) and the outcome (batting performance potential). Conditioning on this collider variable induces a selection bias that can create a spurious association between X and Y. Without knowledge of the excluded players' characteristics (Z), we cannot disentangle whether the higher batting averages among those who practiced more are due to a causal effect or simply because only better-performing players with high practice hours remain in the sample. The critical hidden questionwho is excludeddetermines if the correlation is biased. Hence, causal inference requires understanding the selection mechanism to avoid biased conclusions, emphasizing the need to incorporate data on the full population or adjust for selection bias.

scenario: A football team observes that players who undergo an intensive strength training program (X) tend to have higher on-field performance ratings (Y) during the season. Coaches note that among the current roster, those who completed the program appear to outperform those who did not. However, players who were injured early in the season or dropped out of the training program are excluded from these observations.
claim: Intensive strength training causes better on-field performance in football players.
label: NO

variables.X: Participation in intensive strength training program
variables.Y: On-field performance rating during the season
variables.Z: Player dropout or injury leading to exclusion from observed performance data (selection mechanism)

causal_structure: Participation in strength training (X) is hypothesized to affect performance (Y). However, the observed data only includes players who survived the season without injury or dropout (Z), creating a selection bias. Players who failed the training or got injured are missing from the dataset, which biases the observed association.
key_insight: The observed positive association between training and performance is influenced by excluding players who dropped out or got injured, which distorts the true causal effect of training.
hidden_timestamp: What happened to the players who failed to complete the training or were injured early in the season and thus excluded from observed performance data?

conditional_answers.condition_a: If players who dropped out or were injured mostly had poor performance independent of training, then including them would weaken or negate the positive causal effect of training on performance.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If players who dropped out or were injured had similar or better potential performance, then the positive association observed among survivors might underestimate the true causal benefit of training.

wise_refusal: This claim falls into the T2: SURVIVORSHIP trap because it overlooks players who did not complete the training or were injured and thus are missing from performance observations. Without data on these excluded players (the hidden variable Z), we cannot accurately assess the causal effect of strength training on performance. To resolve this ambiguity, we need to know how the excluded players performed or would have performed if they had remained in the dataset. Without such information, the causal claim that training causes better performance is not justified.
gold_rationale: The observed data is subject to selection bias due to survivorship: only players who completed the training and remained healthy are included in performance ratings. This selection mechanism (Z) collides with the causal pathway from training (X) to performance (Y), creating a distorted association. Without information on the missing subset of players  whether they dropped out due to poor performance potential or unrelated injuries  we cannot disentangle the true causal effect from this bias. The hidden question about what happened to the failures (excluded players) is essential because their outcomes could either diminish or reinforce the observed effect. Hence, any causal inference ignoring this survivorship bias risks being invalid.

scenario: At a national Track and Field championship, data shows that athletes who underwent an intensive sprint training program (X) have faster 100-meter dash times (Y) than those who did not enroll in the program. Observationally, it appears that the training program improves sprint performance. However, the dataset only includes athletes who completed the competition, excluding those who dropped out or were disqualified during preliminary rounds.
claim: Participating in the intensive sprint training program (X) causes athletes to run faster 100-meter dash times (Y).
label: NO

variables.X: Participation in intensive sprint training program
variables.Z: Athlete dropout or disqualification status before final measurement

causal_structure: X  Y, but Z selects which athletes are observed; only survivors (non-dropouts) included, creating a selection bias that makes X and Y appear causally related.
key_insight: The observed association between training and performance is biased because only athletes who survived the preliminary rounds (Z) are included, hiding the fate of those who dropped out or were disqualified.
hidden_timestamp: What happened to the athletes who failed to complete the competitiondid dropout rates differ by training participation?

conditional_answers.condition_a: If most athletes in the training program who dropped out or were disqualified were those who performed poorly, then among survivors the training program genuinely improved performance.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If dropout or disqualification rates were higher among non-training athletes who were weaker, then the observed difference is inflated by excluding poor performers from the non-training group, and the training program may have little or no causal effect.

wise_refusal: This is a classic T2: SURVIVORSHIP selection trap, where only athletes who completed the competition are observed. To resolve the causal ambiguity, we need data on all athletes, including those who dropped out or were disqualified (Z). Without this information, we cannot determine whether the training program truly causes improved sprint times, or if the observed effect is due to differential dropout rates filtering out poorer performers unequally across groups.
gold_rationale: The scenario demonstrates survivorship bias by selecting only athletes who finished the competition, ignoring those who failed early. This hidden selection (Z) acts as a collider that induces a spurious association between training (X) and performance (Y). Without knowing the dropout patterns, we cannot infer causality because the observed data is conditional on survival, skewing the apparent effect. Understanding what happened to the failures is crucial to correctly estimating the causal impact of the training program.

scenario: In a competitive swimming club, it is observed that swimmers who undergo an intensive early morning training program (X) tend to achieve faster race times (Y) in official competitions. Observational data collected only include the race times of swimmers who qualified for the championship final, which are the fastest swimmers. The data do not include those who failed to qualify.
claim: Undergoing the intensive early morning training program (X) causes swimmers to have faster race times (Y).
label: NO

variables.X: Participation in the intensive early morning training program
variables.Y: Race time in official swimming competitions
variables.Z: Qualification for the championship final (selection mechanism)

causal_structure: X influences Y, but Z (qualification status) conditions the observed data; only those who qualify (Z=1) are included in the dataset, creating a selection bias that distorts the apparent causal effect of X on Y.
key_insight: The observed dataset only includes survivors (qualified swimmers), which induces a selection bias that mimics a causal effect of X on Y.
hidden_timestamp: What happened to the swimmers who did not qualify for the finals? Were there early morning trainees among them who performed poorly or dropped out?

conditional_answers.condition_a: If the non-qualifying swimmers who underwent the early morning training had generally worse performances or dropped out early due to overtraining or injury, then the apparent beneficial effect of early morning training among finalists is a selection artifact, not a true causal effect.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If the non-qualifying swimmers who skipped the early morning training were generally worse performers, and early morning training improved performance consistently across all swimmers, then the observed causal claim would be justified.

wise_refusal: This claim falls into the T2: SURVIVORSHIP trap because the data only include swimmers who qualified for the finals, excluding those who did not. To resolve this ambiguity, we need information about the performance and participation of swimmers who failed to qualify (the hidden variable Z). Without knowing what happened to these non-qualifiers, we cannot determine whether the early morning training truly causes faster race times or if the observed effect is due to selection bias.
gold_rationale: The scenario exemplifies the survivorship bias where only 'survivors' (finalists) are observed, creating a misleading association between early morning training (X) and faster race times (Y). Because the dataset excludes those who failed to qualify (Z=0), who might have undergone the same training but had poor outcomes, the causal claim cannot be justified. The hidden question about the non-qualifiers' performance is pivotal: if many early morning trainees failed or underperformed, the observed positive association is biased by selection. Conversely, uniform improvement across all swimmers would support the claim. Thus, without data on the full population, the causal inference is invalid due to the T2 survivorship trap.

scenario: In a competitive cycling tournament, it is observed that cyclists who use a new aerodynamic helmet (X) tend to have faster finishing times (Y) compared to those who do not. The data only includes cyclists who completed the race. However, some cyclists dropped out or crashed during the race and are excluded from the analysis.
claim: Using the new aerodynamic helmet (X) causes cyclists to achieve faster finishing times (Y).
label: NO

variables.X: Use of the new aerodynamic helmet
variables.Z: Cyclist dropout or crash status (selection mechanism)

causal_structure: X -> Y observed only in selected survivors (Z=completed race); Z acts as a collider influenced by both X and other factors affecting dropout
key_insight: The analysis suffers from survivorship bias because only cyclists who finished the race are observed, obscuring the true causal effect of the helmet on finishing time.
hidden_timestamp: What happened to the cyclists who dropped out or crashed during the race?

conditional_answers.condition_a: If the dropped out cyclists mostly did not use the new helmet, then the helmet might indeed improve finishing times for those who can finish.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If the dropped out cyclists mostly used the new helmet and dropped out due to issues related to it, then the helmet could actually harm overall performance or safety, invalidating the claim.

wise_refusal: This claim falls into the T2 survivorship trap because it only analyzes cyclists who finished the race, ignoring those who dropped out or crashed. To resolve the causal ambiguity, we need data on the dropout status and reasons for all cyclists, including those excluded. Without this information, we cannot determine whether the helmet truly improves finishing times or if the observed effect is biased by selective survival.
gold_rationale: The observed association between helmet use and faster finishing times is confounded by selection bias (survivorship). Only cyclists who completed the race are included, but dropout or crash status (Z) is influenced both by helmet use (X) and other risk factors. This creates a collider bias if conditioning on finishing the race. Without knowing the dropout distribution and its relationship to helmet use, we cannot disentangle whether the helmet causally improves performance or simply appears beneficial because less successful or riskier participants are excluded. The key hidden question is what happened to the failures  understanding this would reveal if the helmet genuinely causes improvement or if the result is spurious due to selection. Thus, the causal claim is unjustified without this hidden information.

scenario: In a golf tournament, analysts observe that players who practice a new putting technique (X) tend to have higher scores (Y) among the finalists. However, the analysis only includes golfers who made the cut to play on the final day (Z). Both practicing the new putting technique and having inherently higher skill levels influence whether a player makes the cut. This selection on the cut status creates a collider bias in the observed data.
claim: Practicing the new putting technique causes an increase in players' golf scores among all competitors.
label: NO

variables.Z: Making the cut to play on the final day

causal_structure: X -> Z <- Y
key_insight: Are we conditioning on a collider variable (Z) that is influenced by both X and Y, creating a spurious association between them?
hidden_timestamp: Are we conditioning on a variable caused by both practicing the new putting technique and players' inherent skills affecting their scores?

conditional_answers.condition_a: If making the cut (Z) is primarily driven by practicing the new putting technique (X), then the observed association between X and Y could be biased downward or upward depending on the selection, potentially masking a true beneficial effect of the technique.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If making the cut (Z) is primarily driven by players' inherent skill (which affects Y), then conditioning on Z induces a spurious negative association between practicing the technique (X) and score (Y), making it seem like the technique worsens scores when it may not.

wise_refusal: This claim falls into a T3: COLLIDER trap because the analysis conditions on making the cut (Z), a collider influenced by both practicing the new putting technique (X) and players' inherent skill affecting scores (Y). Without knowing how making the cut is causally related to X and Y, we cannot disentangle whether the observed association is causal or spurious. To resolve this ambiguity, we need data that include players who did not make the cut or an approach that corrects for collider bias. Until then, we cannot validly claim that practicing the new technique causes higher scores.
gold_rationale: In this scenario, conditioning on the collider variable 'making the cut' (Z), which is caused by both the putting technique practiced (X) and players' inherent skill affecting scores (Y), opens a backdoor path creating a spurious association between X and Y. This selection bias makes it appear that practicing the technique influences scores when the observed association is confounded by conditioning on Z. The key hidden questionwhether the conditioning on Z is inducing this biasdetermines if the causal claim is justified. Without unselected data or appropriate adjustment methods, causal inference is invalid. Hence, identifying and understanding the collider structure is essential to avoid misinterpretation of observational data in this Golf subdomain.

scenario: In a volleyball tournament, coaches observe that players who aggressively dive for the ball (X) tend to have fewer successful spikes (Y) in recorded match statistics. However, analysis is performed only on players selected to play in high-stakes matches (Z), which is a variable influenced both by the player's aggressive diving and their spike success rate. This selection criterion creates a dataset where aggressive divers appear to have worse spike outcomes, suggesting a negative causal effect of diving on spiking.
claim: Aggressively diving for the ball (X) causes a decrease in successful spikes (Y) among volleyball players.
label: NO
causal_structure: X  Z  Y (Z is a collider influenced by both X and Y)
key_insight: Are we conditioning on a collider variable (Z) that is caused by both X and Y, thus inducing a spurious association?
hidden_timestamp: Would knowing whether selection for high-stakes matches (Z) is truly influenced by both aggressive diving (X) and spike success (Y) resolve the causal ambiguity?

conditional_answers.condition_a: If selection (Z) depends on both aggressive diving (X) and spike success (Y), then conditioning on Z opens a collider path, creating a spurious negative association between X and Y that does not reflect a true causal effect.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If selection (Z) is independent of either aggressive diving (X) or spike success (Y), then the observed negative association is more likely to represent a genuine causal effect of X on Y.

wise_refusal: This claim falls into the T3: COLLIDER trap because the analysis conditions on selection for high-stakes matches (Z), a variable influenced by both aggressive diving (X) and spike success (Y). Without knowing whether Z truly acts as a collider, we cannot disentangle whether the negative association between X and Y is causal or a spurious artifact. To resolve this ambiguity, we need detailed information on how selection for matches depends on X and Y. Without this, making a causal claim about diving reducing spike success is unjustified.
gold_rationale: The causal structure shows that both aggressive diving (X) and spike success (Y) influence selection for high-stakes matches (Z), making Z a collider. Conditioning on Z, such as analyzing only selected players, opens a non-causal path between X and Y, inducing a spurious association. This selection bias can falsely suggest that diving causes fewer spikes when in fact the relationship is confounded by the collider. Disambiguating this requires understanding the influence of X and Y on Z; only then can causal effects be validly estimated. Hence, causal claims ignoring this collider bias are invalid.

scenario: In rugby, coaches notice that players who both train intensively (X) and have high natural athletic ability (Y) are frequently selected for an elite training camp (Z). Observational data shows a strong association between intensive training and selection to the camp. However, the selection process (Z) depends on both the training intensity and the player's athletic ability, and only those selected are observed for further performance evaluation.
claim: Increasing training intensity (X) causes a higher likelihood of being selected for the elite camp (Z).
label: NO
causal_structure: X  Z  Y
key_insight: The selection to the camp (Z) is a collider variable caused by both training intensity (X) and athletic ability (Y). Conditioning on Z opens a spurious association between X and Y that does not reflect a direct causal effect of X on Z.
hidden_timestamp: Are we conditioning on a variable (Z) that is caused by both training intensity (X) and athletic ability (Y)?

conditional_answers.condition_a: If the selection variable (Z) is conditioned on, then training intensity (X) and athletic ability (Y) appear correlated, but this is due to collider bias and does not imply that training intensity causes better selection outcomes.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If the selection variable (Z) is not conditioned on or properly accounted for, the observed correlation between training intensity (X) and selection disappears, revealing that athletic ability (Y) confounds the relationship and training intensity alone does not cause selection.

wise_refusal: This scenario exemplifies the T3: COLLIDER trap where selection to the elite camp (Z) is influenced by both training intensity (X) and athletic ability (Y). Without knowing whether analyses condition on selection (Z), we cannot infer a causal effect of training intensity on selection. To resolve this ambiguity, we need data or methods that account for the collider structurespecifically, whether selection (Z) is conditioned on. Without this, the causal claim that increasing training intensity causes higher selection likelihood is unjustified due to collider bias.
gold_rationale: In this case, selection to the elite camp (Z) is a collider caused by both training intensity (X) and athletic ability (Y). Conditioning on Z induces a spurious association between X and Y that creates the illusion of a causal effect from X to Z. Because the data only includes players selected to the camp (conditioning on Z), the observed correlation is biased. The hidden questionwhether we are conditioning on Zdirectly determines if the causal claim is valid. If we condition on Z, the bias invalidates the claim. If we do not, the association disappears, showing that training intensity alone does not cause selection. Without clarifying this, the causal inference is not justified.

scenario: In professional hockey, analysts observe that teams with a star goalie (X: having a star goalie) tend to have fewer penalty minutes (Y: fewer penalty minutes) among players on the ice during games. However, the analysis only includes games where the team was tied or losing at the end of the second period (Z: game state selection). This selection criterion inadvertently conditions on a variable caused by both the star goalie presence and the penalty minutes, since a star goalie can influence game state and aggressive play leading to penalties can also affect the score. As a result, the observed negative association between having a star goalie and penalty minutes may be misleading.
claim: Having a star goalie directly causes players to commit fewer penalties during games.
label: NO

variables.Y: Number of penalty minutes among players
variables.Z: Conditioning on games that are tied or losing at the end of the second period

causal_structure: X --> Z <-- Y (Z is a collider influenced by both X and Y)
key_insight: Are we conditioning on a collider variable caused by both the exposure (star goalie) and the outcome (penalty minutes) through the game state selection?
hidden_timestamp: Are we selecting only games based on the score at the end of period two, which is influenced by both the presence of a star goalie and the penalties committed?

conditional_answers.condition_a: If the selection variable Z is truly a collider caused by both having a star goalie and penalty minutes, then conditioning on Z creates a spurious negative association between X and Y. Without this conditioning, the true causal relationship may be null or even positive.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If the selection variable Z is not a collider or not influenced by both X and Y, then the observed negative association would reflect a genuine causal effect of having a star goalie reducing penalties.

wise_refusal: This claim falls into the T3: COLLIDER trap by conditioning on game states (Z) affected by both the presence of a star goalie (X) and penalty minutes (Y). Without knowing whether the analysis conditions on this collider, we cannot disentangle if the negative association is causal or induced by selection bias. To resolve this ambiguity, we need detailed information on the selection criteria and whether the conditioning on game state distorts the relationship. Without this, asserting a direct causal effect is unjustified.
gold_rationale: The scenario exemplifies a collider bias where the variable Z (game state at period two) is influenced by both the exposure X (star goalie) and the outcome Y (penalty minutes). Conditioning on Z opens a non-causal path between X and Y, creating a spurious association. This violates the backdoor criterion for causal inference. Hence, the observed negative association does not imply that having a star goalie causally reduces penalties. The key to disambiguating the causal effect is knowing whether and how conditioning on Z occurs. By answering the hidden question about conditioning, we can determine if the association is biased or genuine. Without this crucial information, the causal claim cannot be substantiated.

scenario: A study observes that marathon runners who start training earlier tend to have higher finishing rates in races. Data shows that runners who began training at least six months before the marathon completed the race more often than those who started later. At first glance, this suggests that early training causally improves the likelihood of finishing the marathon.
claim: Starting marathon training earlier causes runners to finish the race more frequently.
label: NO

variables.X: Time when the runner starts marathon training
variables.Z: Immortal time period before the runner officially begins training

causal_structure: X (early training start)  Y (finishing marathon), but Z (immortal time) creates a selection bias that inflates the observed association.
key_insight: The period between signing up and officially beginning training acts as an immortal time during which the outcome (not finishing because of dropout or injury) cannot occur, biasing the apparent effect of early training.
hidden_timestamp: Was there a time window after runner enrollment but before training start where the outcome (dropping out or failing to finish) could not happen?

conditional_answers.condition_a: If the outcome could not occur during the immortal time (e.g., runners are counted as 'still training' even if they dropped out), then the observed association is biased and does not reflect the true causal effect of early training.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If the outcome could occur immediately upon enrollment (no immortal period), then the observed association more likely reflects a genuine causal effect of starting training early.

wise_refusal: This scenario suffers from the T4: IMMORTAL TIME trap, where an immortal period between enrollment and training start inflates the apparent benefit of early training. To resolve this, we need detailed timing data about when runners could actually fail to finish the marathon relative to their training start date. Without this hidden information, we cannot validly claim that starting training earlier causes higher finishing rates because the analysis may be biased by immortal time.
gold_rationale: Immortal time bias occurs when a period during which the outcome cannot happen is inappropriately attributed to the exposed group, artificially enhancing the exposure's apparent benefit. Here, runners who start training earlier have an inherent immortal time during which they cannot fail to finish, because failure prior to training start is not counted or misclassified. This selection mechanism (Z) induces a spurious association between early training (X) and finishing (Y). Only by knowing whether and when the outcome could occur during this period can we disentangle the true causal effect from bias. Without this information, the causal claim that early training improves finishing rates is not justified.

scenario: A study investigates whether starting an intensive boxing training program (X) reduces the risk of career-ending injuries (Y) among professional boxers. Observational data shows that boxers who begin the training program appear to have longer careers without injury compared to those who never started the program. However, the timing of injury occurrence in relation to when training begins is not carefully accounted for.
claim: Starting the intensive training program causes a reduction in the risk of career-ending injuries for boxers.
label: NO

variables.Z: Immortal time period during which injury could not have occurred before training start

causal_structure: X (training start) temporally follows an 'immortal' period Z during which Y (injury) could not happen; this selection mechanism creates a bias making X appear protective against Y, though causality is not established.
key_insight: There exists an immortal time interval before the start of the training program during which the outcome (injury) cannot occur by definition, biasing the observed association between training and injury risk.
hidden_timestamp: Was there a period after boxer enrollment but before training started during which career-ending injury could not have occurred?

conditional_answers.condition_a: If the immortal time period exists and was long, the observed protective effect of training is largely due to this bias, meaning the training may not truly reduce injury risk.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If no immortal time period exists (injuries could happen before training start but did not), then the observed association might reflect a genuine protective effect of the training.

wise_refusal: This analysis is vulnerable to the T4: IMMORTAL TIME trap, which occurs because the timing of injury relative to training start is not properly accounted for. To resolve this ambiguity, we need detailed time-to-event data capturing when injuries happened in relation to when training began. Without this, we cannot determine if the apparent protective effect is real or simply an artifact of immortal time bias, so the causal claim cannot be justified.
gold_rationale: The T4: IMMORTAL TIME trap arises when the exposure variable (starting intensive training) is defined after a period during which the outcome (career-ending injury) could not have occurred, creating a guaranteed 'immortal' survival period for exposed subjects. Because injuries occurring before training start are excluded by design, the exposed group appears to have a lower risk of injury, inducing bias. Resolving this requires knowing whether such an immortal period exists and its length. If it does, the observed association is confounded by selection bias rather than reflecting a true causal effect. Hence, without this critical timing information, the causal claim that training reduces injury risk is not valid.

scenario: In a professional wrestling league, analysts observe that wrestlers who signed a long-term exclusive contract (X) tend to have longer career durations before retirement (Y). Observational data shows that once a wrestler signs such a contract, their career length appears significantly extended compared to those without. However, this observation ignores that wrestlers cannot retire while under contract, creating a period during which the outcome (retirement) is impossible.
claim: Signing a long-term exclusive contract (X) causes wrestlers to have longer careers (Y).
label: NO

variables.Z: Contract enforcement period where retirement is prohibited (immortal time)

causal_structure: X -> Y, but Z (the immortal time during contract) creates a selection bias that inflates the observed effect of X on Y.
key_insight: The critical hidden information is whether wrestlers are prevented from retiring during the contract period, creating immortal time during which the outcome cannot occur.
hidden_timestamp: Was there a contract-enforced period when retirement (outcome Y) could not have occurred?

conditional_answers.condition_a: If wrestlers are contractually obligated and unable to retire during the contract period (immortal time), then the observed longer career duration is partly an artifact of this forced delay, and the causal effect of signing the contract on career length is overestimated.
conditional_answers.condition_b: If wrestlers could retire anytime despite signing the contract, then the observed association more accurately reflects a causal effect of the contract on career longevity.

wise_refusal: This claim falls into the T4: IMMORTAL TIME trap because it ignores the contract period during which retirement is prohibited. To resolve this causal ambiguity, we need to know if there was a time period post-contract signing when retirement was impossible, effectively delaying the outcome and biasing the association. Without this information, we cannot validly conclude that signing the contract causes longer careers, as the observed effect may be entirely driven by this immortal time bias.
gold_rationale: The observed data shows that wrestlers with long-term contracts have longer careers, suggesting a causal effect. However, the T4 IMMORTAL TIME trap reveals that the period during the contract when retirement cannot occur artificially extends career length, creating a selection bias in observational data. Without knowing whether retirement was indeed impossible during the contract, the causal claim is not justified. If retirement was prohibited, the exposure (contract) only delays the outcome (retirement) rather than causing a true increase in career length. Thus, the hidden question about the existence of immortal time is essential to disambiguate the cause-effect relationship.

scenario: A gymnastics team introduced an intensive strength training program (X) to improve athletes' vault performance (Y). Observational data showed that athletes who participated in the program had higher vault scores during the competition season. The data was collected from the start of the season until the competition date. However, the time period before athletes began the strength training was not accounted for, and some athletes started training at different times during the season. The hidden variable (Z) is the timing of when each gymnast began the strength training program relative to the competition date, which affects the risk period during which improvement in vault performance could be observed.
