key_insight: Never pay for last year's stats.
hidden_timestamp: The contract was signed immediately following the outlier season.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the player demonstrated a sustainable change in launch angle and exit velocity, the decline might be failure.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If 50 HR was just a variance spike, Y is expected.

wise_refusal: The 50 HR season (X) was an outlier performance. Signing him at the peak guarantees he will produce less (Y) simply due to Regression to the Mean (T5). The contract didn't ruin him; statistics did.
gold_rationale: Performance naturally fluctuates. An extreme outlier season (X) is statistically likely to be followed by a season closer to the mean (Y), regardless of the intervention.

scenario: A driver is 20 seconds behind (X). The strategist keeps him out on old tires hoping for a Safety Car. A Safety Car happens (Z), closing the gap and allowing a cheap pit stop. Driver wins (Y). The strategist is hailed as a genius.
claim: The strategy was genius because it resulted in a win.
label: NO
causal_structure: Bad strategy X + Luck Z -> Good Outcome Y
key_insight: Strategies that rely on 5% probability events are usually bad, even if they work.
hidden_timestamp: The probability of a Safety Car was 15%.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the team had weather data or track data suggesting a Safety Car was highly probable (>40%), the strategy was sound.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If they relied on a 15% chance, it was a lucky gamble.

wise_refusal: This is Outcome Bias, a form of statistical artifact (T5). The strategy (X) had a low expected value and relied on a lucky event (Z). Validating the process based on the lucky result (Y) reinforces bad decision-making.
gold_rationale: The positive outcome (Y) was caused by a low-probability external event (Z), not the strategic decision (X). Judging the decision by the outcome ignores the risk taken.

scenario: A study shows that pitchers who consistently throw over 100mph in the majors (X) rarely have elbow surgery (Y). A coach encourages youth pitchers to throw max effort to protect their elbows.
claim: Throwing max effort causes elbow protection.
label: NO
causal_structure: X (100mph) -> Y (Health) in survivors only
key_insight: Survivorship Bias hides the injuries.
hidden_timestamp: Pitchers who blow out their elbows don't make the majors.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If youth pitchers have the same elite connective tissue as the MLB survivors, X applies.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If not, high velocity increases injury risk.

wise_refusal: This is Survivorship Bias (T2). Pitchers who threw 100mph and blew out their elbows (Z) are not in the 'majors' dataset. Only the genetic outliers who could withstand the stress (X) remained.
gold_rationale: The sample excludes failures (Z). The observed relationship in survivors (X -> Y) is an artifact of selection, not a causal mechanism applicable to the general population.

scenario: A golfer is putting terribly (X) and switches to a new brand of putter (I). His putting improves in the next tournament (Y). He claims the new putter is the cause.
claim: The new putter caused the improvement.
label: NO
causal_structure: Switching putter at nadir The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: You change the putter when you can't putt.
hidden_timestamp: The switch happened after the worst round of the year.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the old putter was physically damaged or ill-fitted, the switch (I) caused Y.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the old putter was fine, Z (regression) caused Y.

wise_refusal: Golfers switch putters (I) when their performance is at a trough (X). Improvement (Y) is expected due to Regression to the Mean (T5), regardless of the equipment change.
gold_rationale: Improvement following a performance trough (X) is statistically expected. Attributing it to the intervention (New Putter) ignores natural variance.

scenario: A strict coach uses harsh, abusive training methods (X). His gym produces several Olympic medalists (Y). Parents argue his methods are necessary for success.
claim: Abusive training methods cause Olympic success.
label: NO
causal_structure: Abusive training X selects for survivors Y
key_insight: Harsh methods break the weak; only the strong remain.
hidden_timestamp: 90% of students quit or get injured.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the training method teaches specific technical skills achievable no other way, X causes Y.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If it simply filters for durability, it is survivorship.

wise_refusal: This is Survivorship Bias (T2). The harsh methods (X) filter out everyone except the most resilient genetic outliers (Y). The many athletes broken by the system (Z) are ignored. Success might be despite the training, not because of it.
gold_rationale: The method (X) acts as a filter, not a developer. Observing only the successful survivors (Y) while ignoring the dropouts (Z) creates a false causal link.

scenario: A player appears on the cover of a video game (X) after an MVP season. Next season he is plagued by minor injuries and stats drop (Y). Fans claim he is cursed.
claim: Appearing on the cover caused the performance decline.
label: NO
causal_structure: Cover selection at Peak -> Regression
key_insight: Being on the cover requires being an outlier.
hidden_timestamp: Selection for cover requires peak performance.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the player was concealing an injury at the time of selection, X predicts Y.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Otherwise, it is standard regression.

wise_refusal: The 'Curse' is Regression to the Mean (T5). Only players with outlier seasons (X) are selected for covers. Outlier seasons usually involve good health luck, which normalizes (Y) in subsequent years.
gold_rationale: Selection for the cover (X) is conditioned on peak performance. The subsequent decline (Y) is a statistical certainty (Regression) rather than a causal effect of the cover.

scenario: A study on a new high-intensity workout recruits volunteers (X). The participants show massive fitness gains (Y). The gym markets the workout to the general public.
claim: The workout causes massive gains for the general population.
label: NO
causal_structure: Volunteers for study X differ from population
key_insight: Lazy people don't volunteer for exercise studies.
hidden_timestamp: The study required 6am attendance.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the workout is tested on a random sample of the population, results might hold.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: With volunteers, motivation confounds the result.

wise_refusal: The study suffers from Volunteer Bias (T1). Volunteers (X) are inherently more motivated and disciplined than the general public (Z). The efficacy of the workout is confounded by the participants' drive.
gold_rationale: The sample (Volunteers) is not representative of the target population. The results are likely driven by the trait that caused them to volunteer (Motivation), not just the workout.

scenario: A GM drafts a highly touted QB (X). In his rookie season, he posts average stats (Y). Fans label him a 'bust'. The GM argues that given he had the worst offensive line in the league (Z), average performance is actually promising.
claim: The average stats demonstrate the player is a bust.
label: NO
causal_structure: Context Z explains Outcome Y The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: Stats don't tell the whole story for rookies.
hidden_timestamp: QB was sacked 60 times.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the QB held the ball too long causing the sacks, Y is on him.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the pressure was instantaneous, Y is a team failure, not a player bust.

wise_refusal: This is Confounding (T7). Judging the QB solely on raw stats (Y) ignores the confounding variable of the offensive line (Z). Producing 'average' stats under 'terrible' conditions often indicates above-average skill.
gold_rationale: The claim ignores the confounding context (Z). Performance (Y) is a function of both skill and environment. Attributing Y solely to lack of skill ignores the causal impact of the environment.

scenario: A team loses 4 games in a row (X). The captain holds a 'players only' meeting (I) to scream at everyone. They win the next game (Y). The captain credits the meeting.
claim: The meeting caused the win.
label: NO
causal_structure: Meeting called at losing streak trough
key_insight: Yelling at players works because they were going to win anyway.
hidden_timestamp: Meetings only happen when things are bad.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If tactical changes were made during the meeting, I caused Y.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If it was just emotional yelling, regression (Z) likely explains Y.

wise_refusal: The meeting (I) was triggered by the losing streak (X). Since sports performance fluctuates, the team was statistically likely to win the next game (Y) anyway due to Regression to the Mean (T5).
gold_rationale: Interventions triggered by extreme negative performance (X) often appear effective because performance naturally improves (Regresses) back to the mean (Y), regardless of the intervention.

scenario: A player skips college to go pro (X) citing Kobe Bryant and LeBron James as proof it works. His guidance counselor advises against it.
claim: Skipping college causes NBA stardom.
label: NO
causal_structure: Successful dropouts X visible; failed dropouts Z invisible
key_insight: Kobe made it. Your neighbor didn't.
hidden_timestamp: Dataset includes only NBA All-Stars.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the player has physical metrics comparable to Kobe/LeBron, X might work.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If average, Z applies.

wise_refusal: The player is relying on Survivorship Bias (T2). He sees the superstars who succeeded (X) but ignores the many high schoolers who skipped college, failed to make the NBA, and are currently unemployed (Z).
gold_rationale: The sample is biased towards the survivors (X). The failures (Z) are invisible, leading to an overestimation of the strategy's success rate.

scenario: A coach notices that when he praises a player for a great play (X), the player does worse next time. When he yells at a player for a bad play (X'), the player does better. He concludes punishment is better than praise.
claim: Punishment causes improvement; praise causes decline.
label: NO
causal_structure: Punish after bad (X) -> Better (Y); Reward after good (X') -> Worse (Y')
key_insight: Kahneman's flight instructor example.
hidden_timestamp: Performance oscillates around a mean.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the player wasn't trying, punishment might work.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If they were trying their best, regression explains the fluctuation.

wise_refusal: This is the classic Regression to the Mean trap (T5). A great play (X) is likely followed by a worse one, and a bad play (X') by a better one, regardless of the coach's feedback. The coach is mistaking statistical regression for the effect of his intervention.
gold_rationale: Extreme performance (X) is statistically likely to be followed by average performance (Y). The correlation with feedback is spurious; the change in performance is driven by natural regression.

scenario: Data shows that riders on $10,000 bikes (X) average 5mph faster speeds than riders on $500 bikes (Y). A beginner buys a $10,000 bike expecting to ride 5mph faster.
claim: Buying a $10,000 bike causes a 5mph speed increase.
label: NO
causal_structure: Rich/Serious people buy expensive bikes X
key_insight: It's the rider, not the bike. This highlights the importance of distinguishing correlation from causation.
hidden_timestamp: Only fit, serious cyclists invest in X.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the beginner is already at elite fitness, X helps.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If not, Z (fitness) dominates.

wise_refusal: This is Selection Bias (T1). The group owning $10,000 bikes (X) consists of serious, fit cyclists. The bike contributes marginally, but the speed difference is primarily caused by the rider's fitness (Z).
gold_rationale: The correlation is confounded by rider fitness (Z). Serious cyclists (Z) cause both the purchase of expensive bikes (X) and the high speeds (Y).

scenario: A player wins 'Most Improved Player' (X). The next season, his stats decline slightly (Y). Analysts say he 'rested on his laurels'.
claim: The player's effort declined because he won the award.
label: NO
causal_structure: Award selected on positive delta X -> Y Regression
key_insight: Improvement is rarely linear. This highlights the importance of distinguishing correlation from causation.
hidden_timestamp: The award captures the steepest ascent.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the player is young and developing skills, the improvement might be sticky.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If it was just a hot shooting year, regression occurs.

wise_refusal: The 'Most Improved' award selects for a season where everything went right (X). It is statistically probable that the player will not sustain that rate of growth and will regress toward a more stable mean (Y) next season (T5).
gold_rationale: The award selects for the maximum positive outlier (X). Natural variation dictates that the subsequent season (Y) will likely be closer to the mean, appearing as a decline.

scenario: The league introduces better helmets (X) to reduce concussions. The concussion rate does not drop (Y). Observers blame the helmet design.
claim: The helmets failed to improve safety.
label: NO
causal_structure: Intervention X leads to riskier behavior Z -> Outcome Y
key_insight: Peltzman Effect / Risk Compensation.
hidden_timestamp: Players feel safer.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If player behavior (Z) remains constant, Y should drop.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If risk compensation occurs, Y stays constant.

wise_refusal: This may be Backfire / Risk Compensation (T17). Feeling safer due to better helmets (X), players may have adopted more dangerous tackling techniques (Z), offsetting the safety benefits.
gold_rationale: The intervention (X) caused a behavioral change (Z - Riskier Tackling) which counteracted the mechanical benefit of the helmets. The outcome (Y) is a result of the system response, not just the component failure.

scenario: An analysis of NBA players shows that shorter players (X) have higher free throw percentages than taller players. A coach concludes that being short causes better shooting.
claim: Short stature causes better shooting skill.
label: NO
causal_structure: Collider bias on 'Being in NBA'
key_insight: Short players in the NBA are insanely skilled.
hidden_timestamp: Selection into the NBA requires either Height OR Skill.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If short stature mechanistically aids shooting form, X causes Y.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If it's a collider, Z causes the correlation.

wise_refusal: This is Collider Bias (T3). To make the NBA (Z), you need to be either very tall OR very skilled. Short players in the NBA (X) must be exceptionally skilled (Y) to have made the cut, creating a negative correlation between height and skill within the selected sample.
gold_rationale: The relationship is distorted by conditioning on the collider (Z - NBA Entry). In the general population, height and shooting might be uncorrelated, but within the NBA, they are negatively correlated due to selection criteria.

scenario: A striker scores 8 goals in 5 games (X). In the next 5 games, he scores 0 (Y). Fans claim he has 'lost his confidence'.
claim: Loss of confidence caused the scoring drought.
label: NO
causal_structure: Extreme success X -> Regression Y
key_insight: Streaks end. This highlights the importance of distinguishing correlation from causation.
hidden_timestamp: Sustain rate of 1.6 goals/game is impossible.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If he stopped taking shots, it's confidence.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If he kept shooting but missed, it's likely variance/regression.

wise_refusal: This is Regression to the Mean (T5). 8 goals in 5 games (X) is unsustainable (outlier). Scoring 0 in the next 5 (Y) is a variation that brings his average back to a normal rate. It's variance, not necessarily psychology.
gold_rationale: The hot streak (X) was a statistical outlier driven by positive variance. The subsequent drought (Y) is a return to the mean. Attributing it to a psychological cause assumes the outlier was the baseline.

scenario: A 1920s baseball star smoked cigars and ate hot dogs (X) yet played until 40. A modern player adopts this diet to improve longevity.
claim: Bad diet causes longevity.
label: NO
causal_structure: Unhealthy habits X only visible in superstars Y
key_insight: If you smoke and play, you must be Babe Ruth.
hidden_timestamp: Mediocre players with bad diets washed out early.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the modern player shares the specific genetic mutations (Z) of the star, it might work.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If not, X is harmful.

wise_refusal: Survivorship Bias (T2). The 1920s star (Y) had such elite genetics (Z) that he succeeded *despite* the bad diet (X). Lesser athletes with that diet failed and were forgotten, leaving only the 'immortal' survivors visible.
gold_rationale: The sample of 'old school stars' is biased towards those with extreme genetic durability (Z). Their success (Y) occurred in spite of their habits (X), not because of them.

scenario: A manager wins 'Manager of the Month' (X) after a 5-game win streak. The team loses the very next game (Y). The media calls it a 'curse'.
claim: The award caused the loss.
label: NO
causal_structure: Award X given at peak -> Y Regression
key_insight: The curse of the Manager of the Month.
hidden_timestamp: Awards lag performance.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the streak was due to weak opponents, Y is regression.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If it was a tactical breakthrough, the streak might continue.

wise_refusal: The 'Manager of the Month' award selects for a peak performance streak (X). It is statistically expected that the team will not sustain that win rate and will regress (Y) immediately after the award period (T5).
gold_rationale: The award (X) identifies a peak. Movement away from the peak (Y) is statistical regression. The causal attribution to the award (The Curse) is fallacious.

scenario: A scout notices that 40% of NHL starters (elite players) are born in January-March (X). He decides to only draft players born in those months, believing they are genetically superior.
claim: Being born in Q1 causes genetic superiority in hockey.
label: NO
causal_structure: Birth month affects selection X
key_insight: Relative Age Effect. This highlights the importance of distinguishing correlation from causation.
hidden_timestamp: Youth hockey cutoff is Jan 1.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the age cutoff changes, the bias shifts.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the cutoff remains Jan 1, the bias persists.

wise_refusal: This is the Relative Age Effect (Selection T1). Players born in Q1 (X) were the oldest in their youth cohorts (Z), getting better coaching and selection. By draft age, the biological advantage is gone; selecting for it now is an error.
gold_rationale: The correlation is driven by the youth system's age cutoff (Z), which favored older kids. This is a selection artifact, not a genetic causal link.

scenario: A quarterback throws a desperation 'Hail Mary' pass (X) into triple coverage and it is caught for a touchdown (Y). The coach designs more plays throwing into triple coverage.
claim: Throwing into triple coverage is a high-success strategy.
label: NO
causal_structure: Low prob event X succeeds Y The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: Don't plan for miracles. This highlights the importance of distinguishing correlation from causation.
hidden_timestamp: Success rate is < 1%.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the receiver is 7ft tall and opponents are 5ft, X might work.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Otherwise, it is a negative expected value play.

wise_refusal: This is Outcome Bias, a statistical artifact (T5). The success of the Hail Mary (Y) was a high-variance lucky event (Z). Throwing into triple coverage (X) is generally a negative Expected Value strategy. Generalizing from a miracle is irrational.
gold_rationale: The outcome (Y) was determined by variance (Z), not the quality of the decision (X). The strategy remains poor despite the lucky result.

scenario: The batting champion hits .360 (X) this year. Next year he hits .320 (Y). Fans claim he is distracted by his new fame.
claim: Fame caused the decline in batting average.
label: NO
causal_structure: Top performer X declines Y The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: The batting champion rarely repeats.
hidden_timestamp: X requires variance in positive direction.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If his underlying exit velocity and contact rates dropped, X might be distraction.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If his BABIP (luck) simply normalized, it is regression.

wise_refusal: Winning a batting title (X) usually requires career-best luck on balls in play. A drop to .320 (Y) is a natural regression to the player's true talent level (T5), not evidence of distraction (Z).
gold_rationale: The peak performance (X) was an outlier. The decline (Y) is statistical regression. Attributing the decline to a narrative cause (Distraction) is fallacious without evidence of skill loss.

scenario: An analyst notes that fighters who win (Y) usually look less tired (X) in the post-fight interview. He advises fighters to 'look fresh' to convince judges to give them the win.
claim: Looking fresh causes winning.
label: NO
causal_structure: Winners look fresh X The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: Winning makes you less tired. This highlights the importance of distinguishing correlation from causation.
hidden_timestamp: The fight happens before the interview.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If looking fresh influences judges in close rounds, X causes Y.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If X is purely a result of taking less damage, causality is reversed.

wise_refusal: Reverse Causality/Common Cause (T10). Fighters look fresh (X) because they dominated the fight and took less damage (Z), which is also why they won (Y). Faking freshness won't change the fight result.
gold_rationale: The causal direction is reversed or confounded. Performance (Z) causes both Winning (Y) and Freshness (X). Manipulating X does not affect Y.

scenario: A defense forces 40 turnovers in a season (X), a league record. The next season, they force 20 (Y). The coordinator is fired for the decline.
claim: The decline was caused by poor coaching/scheme failure.
label: NO
causal_structure: Turnovers are lucky. The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: Defensive turnovers are not sticky.
hidden_timestamp: Turnovers have low year-to-year correlation.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the scheme relied on specific players who left, the drop is causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If personnel remained same, the drop is regression.

wise_refusal: Turnover generation (X) is highly dependent on luck (fumble bounces, dropped interceptions). A record season is almost always followed by regression (Y). The decline was statistical gravity (T5), not a coaching failure.
gold_rationale: Extreme turnover numbers (X) are unsustainable outliers driven by variance. The return to average (Y) is regression, not a causal indicator of skill decline.

scenario: A team surveys its season ticket holders (X) and finds 95% satisfaction. They decide no changes are needed to the stadium experience, despite falling attendance.
claim: The stadium experience is satisfactory for all fans.
label: NO
causal_structure: We only hear from current season ticket holders.
key_insight: Churned customers don't fill out surveys.
hidden_timestamp: Survey sent with renewal packet.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the survey included non-renewing customers (Z), the conclusion might hold.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only current holders, it is biased.

wise_refusal: Survivorship Bias (T2). The survey only captures those who stayed (X). The unhappy fans who cancelled their tickets (Z) are excluded, likely hiding major issues with the stadium experience.
gold_rationale: The sample (X) excludes the 'failures' (Z - Churned Customers). This biases the result (Y) positively and invalidates the conclusion about the general population.

scenario: A team fires their manager after a 5-game losing streak (X) and appoints an interim coach. The team wins the next 3 games (Y). The board hires the interim coach permanently, but results immediately return to average.
claim: The interim coach caused the winning streak.
label: NO
causal_structure: Interim appointed at trough -> Bounce
key_insight: New manager bounce is often regression.
hidden_timestamp: Firing happens at the statistical bottom.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the interim coach changed tactics significantly, X caused Y.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If he played the same system, Y is regression.

wise_refusal: The 'New Manager Bounce' is often Regression to the Mean (T5). Managers are fired at the nadir of performance (X). Results naturally improve (Y) as bad luck normalizes, regardless of the new coach's ability.
gold_rationale: The timing of the intervention (Firing) coincides with the statistical trough (X). The subsequent improvement (Y) is largely natural regression, not necessarily the causal effect of the new manager.

scenario: A coach goes for a 2-point conversion (X) to win the game and fails (Y). Fans say he should have kicked the extra point to tie because 'he lost the game'.
claim: The decision was wrong because it failed.
label: NO

Z: Kick (Prob 95% to tie, 50% to win OT)

causal_structure: Decision X -> Fail Y The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: Process > Outcome. This highlights the importance of distinguishing correlation from causation.
hidden_timestamp: Win probability of X > Z.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the team's short-yardage offense was decimated by injury, kicking might have been better.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If standard conversion rates apply, going for 2 was correct.

wise_refusal: This is Outcome Bias (T5/Statistical Artifact). If the 2-point conversion success rate is > 50%, going for the win (X) is the correct strategic play. Judging it as 'wrong' because it failed (Y) ignores the probabilities at the moment of decision.
gold_rationale: The quality of the decision (X) is determined by expected value, not the single outcome (Y). The failure was variance, not strategic error.

scenario: A player breaks records at the Scouting Combine for speed and jumping (X). He is drafted high but fails in the NFL (Y). The GM is confused why the athleticism didn't translate.
claim: Combine athleticism causes NFL success.
label: NO
causal_structure: Selection on raw athleticism X
key_insight: Combine warriors often can't play football.
hidden_timestamp: Combine measures athleticism, not skill.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the player also had elite college game tape, the bust was unpredictable.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If tape was poor, X was a false signal.

wise_refusal: Selection Bias/Proxy Error (T1). The Combine (X) selects for raw athleticism, not football skill (Z). Selecting purely on physical outliers often misses the actual cause of performance (skill), leading to busts (Y).
gold_rationale: The selection criteria (X) is a poor proxy for the outcome (Y). Athleticism is necessary but not sufficient; ignoring the unmeasured variable (Z - Skill) leads to false causal predictions.

scenario: A goalkeeper saves 3 penalties in a shootout (X). In the next shootout, he saves zero (Y). Fans claim he lost his focus.
claim: Loss of focus caused the performance drop.
label: NO
causal_structure: Goalie saves 3 in a row X -> Saves 0 next time Y
key_insight: Penalty saving is luck-heavy. This highlights the importance of distinguishing correlation from causation.
hidden_timestamp: Penalty save rate is ~20%.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the goalkeeper has a read on the shooter's cues, the saves are skill.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If he is guessing, it is variance.

wise_refusal: Saving 3 penalties (X) is a massive statistical outlier. In the next shootout, the goalkeeper regressed to the expected save rate (Y). It is not a loss of focus (Z), but a return to probability (T5).
gold_rationale: The initial performance (X) was an outlier driven by variance. The subsequent performance (Y) is regression to the mean. Attributing it to psychology (Z) is a causal fallacy.

scenario: A team adopts a GPS tracker (X) used by the league champions. They assume it caused the championship.
claim: The GPS tracker causes championships.
label: NO
causal_structure: Successful wearables X vs Failed wearables Z
key_insight: We copy the winner. This highlights the importance of distinguishing correlation from causation.
hidden_timestamp: Tech vendor sells to everyone.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the tracker provides unique proprietary data only the champions could interpret, it might be causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If everyone has it, it provides no relative advantage.

wise_refusal: Survivorship Bias (T2). The team looks at the champions (Y) who use the tracker (X) but ignores the relegated teams (Z) who also used the same tracker. The tech is likely uncorrelated with winning.
gold_rationale: Observing the trait (X) only in the winner (Y) ignores the base rate of X in the losers (Z). If Z also has X, then X is not the cause of Y.

scenario: A mid-table team is leading the league at Christmas (X). They fade and finish 5th (Y). Pundits say they 'ran out of gas'.
claim: Physical fatigue ('running out of gas') caused the decline.
label: NO
causal_structure: Leading at Christmas X -> Not winning title Y
key_insight: Early leaders often overperform xG.
hidden_timestamp: Team outperformed xG by 15 goals in first half.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the team suffered key injuries in the second half, 'running out of gas' might be true.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the squad was healthy, regression to expected goals (xG) is the likely cause.

wise_refusal: The team likely outperformed their underlying metrics (xG) in the first half (X). The second half (Y) was a regression to their true quality level (T5), not necessarily a physical collapse.
gold_rationale: The early overperformance (X) was an unsustainable statistical anomaly. The result (Y) is regression to the underlying performance metrics (Z), not a physical failure.

scenario: A TV poll asks 'Should the coach be fired?' 80% say Yes (X). The team fires the coach. Later polls show the silent majority supported him.
claim: 80% of all fans wanted the coach fired.
label: NO
causal_structure: Who votes in polls? The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: Angry people vote. This highlights the importance of distinguishing correlation from causation.
hidden_timestamp: Poll conducted after a loss.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the poll was a random sample of season ticket holders, it is valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If it was an open Twitter poll, it is selected for outrage.

wise_refusal: Selection Bias (T1). TV polls (X) attract the most motivated (angry) viewers, especially after a loss. They do not represent the entire fanbase (Z), leading to a false consensus effect.
gold_rationale: The sample (X) is self-selected based on strong emotion (Anger). This makes it unrepresentative of the population (Z), invalidating the claim.

scenario: A team leads by 20. They slow down to burn clock (X) and end up losing (Y). The coach says 'the strategy was sound, we just missed shots'.
claim: The strategy was sound despite the loss.
label: NO
causal_structure: Passivity X -> Loss Y The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: Playing not to lose is losing.
hidden_timestamp: Efficiency drops in slow pace.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the team missed open layups, the coach is right.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the slow pace forced bad shots, the strategy (X) caused the loss.

wise_refusal: This is likely a Backfire effect (T17). Switching to 'prevent' offense (X) often reduces offensive efficiency and rhythm. The loss (Y) was likely caused by the change in strategy, not just bad luck.
gold_rationale: The intervention (X) fundamentally altered the game dynamics (Z). Attributing the loss (Y) to bad luck ('missing shots') ignores the causal link between the passive strategy and the collapse.

scenario: A team builds a billion-dollar stadium (X). The next year, the local economy enters a recession (Y). Critics blame the stadium spending.
claim: Stadium construction caused the recession.
label: NO
causal_structure: Stadium built at economic peak X -> Recession Y
key_insight: The skyscraper curse. This highlights the importance of distinguishing correlation from causation.
hidden_timestamp: Major projects start at market tops.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the stadium debt directly caused municipal bankruptcy, X caused Y.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the recession was national/global, Z caused Y.

wise_refusal: Major construction projects (X) are usually greenlit at the peak of an economic cycle. A recession (Y) often follows the peak naturally (Z). The stadium didn't cause the recession; the cycle did (T7).
gold_rationale: The timing is correlational due to the economic cycle (Z). Peak confidence drives construction (X), and is naturally followed by a downturn (Y). There is no direct causal mechanism.

scenario: An observer notes that everyone at the Crossfit gym is ripped (X). He concludes Crossfit guarantees getting ripped.
claim: Joining Crossfit causes you to get ripped.
label: NO
causal_structure: Only the fit survive X The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: You have to be fit to do Crossfit.
hidden_timestamp: Unfit people quit within a month.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the gym has a 0% churn rate, the conclusion is valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If high churn (Z), it is survivorship bias.

wise_refusal: Survivorship Bias (T2). The observer sees only the survivors (X). People who don't get ripped or get injured (Z) quit the gym and disappear from the sample, creating a skewed perception of efficacy.
gold_rationale: The sample (X) is filtered for success. The high attrition rate of non-responders (Z) means the observed group is not representative of the treatment effect on a random individual.

scenario: A team goes undefeated 4-0 in the pre-season (X). Fans bet on them to win the Super Bowl. They start the regular season 0-4 (Y).
claim: Pre-season success predicts regular season success.
label: NO
causal_structure: Pre-season performance X uncorrelated with Season Y
key_insight: Winning when it doesn't count means nothing.
hidden_timestamp: Starters played 1 series per game in X.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the starters played the full pre-season games, X might predict Y.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Since they didn't (Z), X is noise.

wise_refusal: Pre-season games (X) are played primarily by reserves (Z). Success there often indicates depth but has zero correlation with regular season success (Y) where starters play. The 0-4 start is a regression to the true talent level of the starters.
gold_rationale: The input data (X) is drawn from a different distribution (Reserves) than the outcome data (Y - Starters). Extrapolating X to Y commits a category error.

scenario: A Grand Slam winner says the secret to success is 'Just have fun' (X). A junior player decides to stop training hard and just have fun, expecting to win.
claim: Having fun causes Grand Slam success.
label: NO
causal_structure: Winner says 'Just have fun' X The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: Losers also had fun. This highlights the importance of distinguishing correlation from causation.
hidden_timestamp: Winner also trained 8 hours a day.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If 'having fun' is the only variable differing between winners and losers, the advice is valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If losers also had fun (Z), the advice is survivorship bias.

wise_refusal: Survivorship Bias (T2). Many players who 'just had fun' (Z) never won and aren't interviewed. The winner (Y) succeeded due to talent and training, perhaps *despite* the attitude.
gold_rationale: The advice (X) comes only from the survivor (Y). It ignores the confounding variables (Talent, Training) and the fact that X is likely prevalent in the invisible losers (Z).

scenario: A player heaves a desperation full-court shot with 20 seconds left on the shot clock (X). It miraculously goes in (Y). The coach applauds the player's 'confidence'.
claim: The shot selection was good because it went in.
label: NO
causal_structure: Bad process X -> Good outcome Y
key_insight: Don't praise bad decisions just because they worked.
hidden_timestamp: The expected value of the shot was 0.05 points.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the shot clock was expiring, X was necessary.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If plenty of time remained, X was a bad decision regardless of Y.

wise_refusal: This is Outcome Bias, a form of statistical artifact (T5). The shot (X) had negative Expected Value and succeeded only due to variance (Z). Praising the decision reinforces bad process that will lead to losses in the long run.
gold_rationale: The outcome (Y) was a statistical anomaly (Z). Validating the decision (X) based on the anomaly ignores the negative expected value of the action.

scenario: A scout signs a player solely based on a 5-minute YouTube highlight reel (X). The player turns out to be terrible, constantly making defensive errors (Y). The scout is shocked.
claim: The highlight reel accurately represented the player's skill.
label: NO
causal_structure: Selected clips X -> False impression of skill Y
key_insight: Highlights hide mistakes. This highlights the importance of distinguishing correlation from causation.
hidden_timestamp: The video excluded 90 minutes of errors.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the video showed every touch (complete game), the assessment is valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If edited clips, it is selection bias.

wise_refusal: Selection Bias (T1). Highlight reels (X) specifically select positive outcomes and exclude errors (Z). Evaluating a player without seeing their mistakes creates a skewed perception of ability (Y).
gold_rationale: The evidence (X) is a non-random sample of the player's performance. By definition, it excludes negative data points (Z), making valid inference about total skill (Y) impossible.

scenario: An analyst highlights an undrafted player who became a star (X) and argues teams should trade their draft picks because 'talent can be found anywhere'.
claim: Draft picks are unnecessary because undrafted players can be stars.
label: NO
causal_structure: We notice the undrafted player who makes it.
key_insight: Nobody talks about the 500 undrafted players who failed.
hidden_timestamp: Success rate of undrafted is < 1%.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the success rate of undrafted players equaled drafted players, the argument holds.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Since it is <1%, it is selection bias.

wise_refusal: Survivorship Bias / Anecdotal Fallacy (T2). The analyst focuses on the rare anomaly (X) while ignoring the thousands of undrafted players who never play a minute (Z). Draft picks remain the most reliable source of talent.
gold_rationale: The claim generalizes from an outlier (X) to the population. It ignores the base rate of failure (Z) in the undrafted population, leading to an incorrect valuation of draft picks.

scenario: A city wins the bid to host the Olympics (X) by promising the most lavish facilities. Ten years later, the city is in debt (Y).
claim: Winning the bid caused the debt.
label: NO
causal_structure: Host city selection X -> Debt Y
key_insight: The winner's curse in auctions.
hidden_timestamp: The winner is the one who overestimates benefits most.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the bid was fully privately funded with guarantees, Y might be avoided.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If public funding with cost overruns, Y is the Winner's Curse.

wise_refusal: The Winner's Curse (T5). The city that wins the bid (X) is the one that most overestimated the benefits and underestimated the costs. Financial regression (Y) is the expected outcome of winning an auction with uncertain value.
gold_rationale: The selection mechanism (Auction) ensures that the winner (X) is the most optimistic outlier. The outcome (Y) is a regression to the true value (Z), revealing the error in the initial estimate.

scenario: A cornerback wins Defensive Player of the Year (X) with 10 interceptions. Next year he has 2 (Y). Fans say he is 'washed'.
claim: Skill decline ('washed') caused the drop in interceptions.
label: NO
causal_structure: DPOY X -> Regression Y The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: Interceptions are luck. This highlights the importance of distinguishing correlation from causation.
hidden_timestamp: Targets are random.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the player lost speed/athleticism (Z), the claim is valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If physical metrics are stable, Y is regression.

wise_refusal: Interceptions are high-variance events. 10 interceptions (X) is a statistical outlier. Dropping to 2 (Y) is regression to the mean (T5), not necessarily a loss of skill.
gold_rationale: The initial performance (X) was an outlier. The subsequent performance (Y) is a return to the mean. Attributing it to a structural change (Z - Washed) is a causal fallacy.

scenario: A player makes a mathematically terrible bluff (X) but the opponent accidentally folds the winning hand (Y). The player thinks he played it perfectly.
claim: The bluff was a good play because it worked.
label: NO
causal_structure: Bad bluff X -> Opponent folds Y
key_insight: Don't bluff a calling station.
hidden_timestamp: Opponent misread his own cards.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the player had a read that the opponent would fold any hand, X is good.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If playing Game Theory Optimal (GTO), X is a mistake.

wise_refusal: This is Outcome Bias/Luck (T5). The bluff (X) had negative Expected Value. The win (Y) was due to the opponent's mistake (Z), not the player's skill. Repeating this strategy will lead to losses.
gold_rationale: The outcome (Y) relied on an external error (Z), not the quality of the strategy (X). Judging the process by the lucky result invalidates the decision analysis.

scenario: A coach builds his team entirely from the transfer portal (X). He is surprised when the team lacks chemistry and discipline (Y).
claim: The transfer portal caused the lack of chemistry.
label: NO
causal_structure: Transfers X are unhappy players
key_insight: Happy players don't transfer. This highlights the importance of distinguishing correlation from causation.
hidden_timestamp: Players enter portal because they didn't fit elsewhere.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the coach vets for character, X can work.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If he ignores the selection bias of why players leave (Z), Y occurs.

wise_refusal: Adverse Selection (T1). Players in the portal (X) often left their previous teams due to playing time issues or conflicts (Z). Aggregating them can concentrate these negative traits, leading to chemistry issues (Y).
gold_rationale: The sample (X) is self-selected for dissatisfaction or conflict (Z). Relying on this pool without accounting for the selection mechanism introduces confounding variables that cause the outcome (Y).

scenario: A team leads the league in penalties (X) in the first half. In the second half, their penalties drop significantly (Y). The coach claims his discipline lectures worked.
claim: The lectures caused the drop in penalties.
label: NO
causal_structure: Most penalized team X -> Referees adjust Y
key_insight: Refs even things up. This highlights the importance of distinguishing correlation from causation.
hidden_timestamp: Outliers regress.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the team changed its aggressive style, the lectures worked.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If they played the same way, Y is regression/officiating balance.

wise_refusal: Regression to the Mean (T5) and Incentives. Extreme penalty rates (X) are unsustainable due to regression and league suspension caps that force players to dial it back (Z). The drop (Y) is likely a natural statistical correction.
gold_rationale: The extreme behavior (X) is an outlier. The return to normal (Y) is expected due to regression and system constraints (Z). Attributing it to the lecture is a causal fallacy.

scenario: A young goalkeeper copies the risky 'sweeper-keeper' style (X) of a World Cup winner. He concedes 5 goals (Y) and is benched.
claim: The sweeper-keeper style causes success.
label: NO
causal_structure: Sweeper Keepers X succeed Y The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: If you aren't Neuer, don't try it.
hidden_timestamp: Only elite keepers survive playing X.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the young keeper has the same elite footwork as the pro, X works.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If not, Z prevents success.

wise_refusal: Survivorship Bias (T2). We only see the elite goalkeepers who successfully play the risky style (X). We forget the many who tried it, failed (Y), and were relegated. The style requires specific attributes the young keeper likely lacks.
gold_rationale: The success of the model (X) is conditioned on elite skill (Z). Applying X without Z leads to failure (Y). The observed success is biased by survivorship.

scenario: A Running Back runs for 200 yards and wins Player of the Week (X). You bet on him to go Over 100 yards next week. He runs for 60 (Y).
claim: The player should have continued his high performance.
label: NO
causal_structure: Player of Week X -> Average Game Y
key_insight: Don't chase the heat. This highlights the importance of distinguishing correlation from causation.
hidden_timestamp: Average is 80 yards.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the opponent next week has a terrible defense, betting over might be valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If standard conditions, expect regression from X.

wise_refusal: Regression to the Mean (T5). A 200-yard game (X) is a massive outlier. Betting on a repeat ignores that the player is statistically likely to return to his average (Y) immediately.
gold_rationale: The initial performance (X) was an outlier. Predicting Y based on X ignores the probability distribution, which favors a return to the mean.

scenario: A star plays on a broken foot (X) and helps the team win (Y). The media glorifies his 'heart'. Doctors say he risked career-ending injury.
claim: Playing injured was a good decision.
label: NO
causal_structure: Playing injured X -> Win Y The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: Heroism vs Stupid Risk. This highlights the importance of distinguishing correlation from causation.
hidden_timestamp: Win probability increased by 5%, Risk by 50%.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the win secured a championship, the risk (X) might be rational.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If a regular season game, it was outcome-biased recklessness.

wise_refusal: This is Outcome Bias (T5/Statistical Artifact). The win (Y) blinds observers to the catastrophic risk (Z) taken by playing (X). If he had suffered the career-ending injury, the decision would be viewed as reckless.
gold_rationale: The positive outcome (Y) is used to validate a high-risk decision (X). This ignores the expected cost (Z) which likely outweighed the expected benefit at the time of the decision.

scenario: Social media is full of clips of referees making mistakes (X). A fan concludes referees are worse today than 20 years ago (Y).
claim: Referees are objectively worse today than in the past.
label: NO
causal_structure: We only notice bad calls X The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: Nobody tweets 'Nice call ref'.
hidden_timestamp: HD cameras capture everything now.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If statistical analysis of all calls shows a decline in accuracy, Y is valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If based only on viral clips (X), it is bias.

wise_refusal: Selection/Availability Bias (T1). Social media selects and amplifies mistakes (X) while ignoring the thousands of correct calls (Z). High-definition replay also makes errors more visible than in the past, creating an illusion of decline (Y).
gold_rationale: The evidence (X) is a biased sample selected for outrage. It excludes the vast majority of correct decisions (Z), invalidating the comparative claim (Y).

scenario: A team wins a match 7-0 (X), scoring on every shot. The next week they play a 0-0 draw (Y). Fans joke 'they used up all their goals'.
claim: Using up goals caused the subsequent drought.
label: NO
causal_structure: Extreme performance X -> Regression Y
key_insight: Goals are not a finite resource, but variance is.
hidden_timestamp: XG in first game was only 2.5.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the 7-0 was against a relegated team and the 0-0 against the champion, opponent strength explains Y.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If opponents were equal, regression explains Y.

wise_refusal: Regression to the Mean (T5). The 7-0 win (X) likely involved unsustainable finishing luck (scoring on every chance). The 0-0 draw (Y) represents a return to normal finishing variance, not a mystical depletion of a goal quota.
gold_rationale: The performance (X) was an outlier driven by positive variance. The next result (Y) is independent but statistically likely to be lower (Regression). The 'goal quota' is a magical thinking fallacy.

scenario: A coach teaches kids to swing at bad pitches because a Hall of Famer (X) was famous for hitting bad pitches.
claim: Swinging at bad pitches causes success.
label: NO
causal_structure: HoF players X had specific style
key_insight: Don't teach kids to swing like Vlad Guerrero.
hidden_timestamp: X had superhuman hand-eye coordination.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the kids have the same elite hand-eye coordination as X, it works.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If not, Z (failure) is the result.

wise_refusal: Survivorship Bias (T2). The Hall of Famer (X) succeeded *despite* his bad pitch selection due to freakish hand-eye coordination. Most players who swing at bad pitches (Z) strike out and do not make the Hall of Fame.
gold_rationale: The strategy (X) is observed only in the survivor (Y). It ignores the confounding variable (Elite Coordination) and the base rate of failure (Z) associated with the strategy in the general population.

scenario: A player gets 20 sacks (X) but has a low pressure rate. Analysts predict he will regress next year. Fans call the analysts 'haters'. He gets 8 sacks next year (Y).
claim: The analysts were biased haters.
label: NO
causal_structure: Sack conversion rate X is unstable
key_insight: Sacks are rarer than pressures.
hidden_timestamp: Pressure rate predicts future sacks better than past sacks.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the player improved his technique to win quickly, X might sustain.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Since pressure rate (Z) was low, regression is expected.

wise_refusal: Sack totals (X) are volatile and depend on finishing luck. Pressure rate (Z) is a more stable indicator of skill. The drop to 8 sacks (Y) is a predictable regression (T5) because his underlying pressure metrics did not support the 20-sack outlier.
gold_rationale: The initial performance (X) was unsupported by underlying skill metrics (Z). The outcome (Y) is a regression to the level predicted by Z, validating the statistical model over the 'haters' narrative.

scenario: A study compares hospital patients who received a new drug (X) vs. those who didn't (Control). Patients had to survive at least 5 days in the hospital to receive the drug. The drug group had higher survival rates (Y).
claim: The drug caused the higher survival rates.
label: NO
causal_structure: Treatment group definition requires survival
key_insight: You can't die during the waiting period if you are in the treatment group.
hidden_timestamp: Treatment assignment happened 5 days post-admission.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the analysis accounted for the 5-day 'immortal' period (time-dependent covariate), the result might be valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the 5-day wait was counted as survival time for the treatment group but risk time for controls, it is biased.

wise_refusal: This is Immortal Time Bias (T4). Patients in the treatment group (X) were guaranteed to survive the first 5 days (the waiting period), whereas controls could die during that time. The survival advantage is built into the group definition.
gold_rationale: The treatment group includes a period of 'immortal time' where death was impossible by definition. Comparing this directly to the control group inflates the survival benefit of the drug.

scenario: Data shows that countries with higher fat consumption (X) have longer life expectancies (Y). A diet guru advises individuals to eat more fat to live longer.
claim: Eating more fat causes individuals to live longer.
label: NO
causal_structure: Group correlation does not imply individual causation
key_insight: Wealthier countries eat more fat and have better healthcare.
hidden_timestamp: Data is aggregated by country.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If individual-level data confirms the trend within countries, it might be valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the trend disappears at the individual level (wealthy people in wealthy countries live longer regardless of fat), it is an fallacy.

wise_refusal: This is the Ecological Fallacy (T6). The correlation exists at the country level because wealthier countries (Z) consume more fat (X) and have better healthcare (Y). This does not mean eating fat helps an individual live longer.
gold_rationale: Inferences about individual behavior cannot be reliably drawn from aggregate group-level data. The group-level correlation is likely confounded by country-level wealth (Z).

scenario: Drug A has a higher overall recovery rate than Drug B (X). However, Drug B performs better for mild cases AND better for severe cases (Z). Doctors are unsure which to prescribe.
claim: Drug A is the better treatment.
label: NO
causal_structure: Aggregate trend reverses in subgroups
key_insight: Drug A was given to easier cases.
hidden_timestamp: Drug A was preferentially prescribed to mild cases.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If you don't know the severity, A has a higher raw probability.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If you know the severity (which you do), Drug B is always superior.

wise_refusal: This is Simpson's Paradox (T8). Drug A's higher overall rate is an artifact of being given primarily to mild cases (Z), who recover often. Since Drug B is superior in both specific subgroups, Drug B is the causally superior treatment.
gold_rationale: Stratifying by the confounder (Severity Z) reveals the true causal relationship. Drug B is superior in every stratum, but the aggregate data is skewed by the uneven distribution of cases.

scenario: Regular exercise (X) is associated with lower cholesterol (Z) and reduced heart disease (Y). It is unclear if people with naturally low cholesterol find it easier to exercise, or if exercise lowers cholesterol.
claim: Exercise causes reduced heart disease via cholesterol.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z could be Confounder (Z->X) or Mediator (X->Z)
key_insight: Timing of Z determines its role.
hidden_timestamp: Did low cholesterol precede exercise habits?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Z precedes X, it is a confounder (healthier people exercise).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If X precedes Z, it is a mediator (exercise lowers cholesterol).

wise_refusal: This is a Confounder-Mediator Ambiguity (T9). We do not know if Low Cholesterol (Z) is a result of Exercise (X) or a pre-existing genetic trait that makes exercise easier. Without temporal data, we cannot attribute the benefit to X.
gold_rationale: The causal role of Z depends entirely on its timing relative to X. If Z is pre-existing, it confounds the X-Y relationship. If Z follows X, it mediates it.

scenario: A study finds a strong correlation between a child's reading ability (X) and their enjoyment of reading (Y). Teachers try to force children to read more to increase enjoyment.
claim: Increasing reading skill causes increased enjoyment.
label: NO
causal_structure: X causes Y AND Y causes X The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: Skill and enjoyment reinforce each other.
hidden_timestamp: Cross-sectional data cannot separate the loop.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the intervention forces reading without building skill, enjoyment may drop (Reactance).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If skill acquisition is prioritized, enjoyment may follow.

wise_refusal: This involves a Feedback Loop (T11). Skill (X) and Enjoyment (Y) likely cause each other bidirectionally. Assuming a simple one-way causal path (X->Y) ignores the cycle and may lead to ineffective interventions.
gold_rationale: The relationship is bidirectional (X <-> Y). Intervening on X does not guarantee Y if the feedback mechanism involves voluntary participation, which forced reading undermines.

scenario: Doctors adjust the dose of a blood pressure drug (X) based on the patient's previous blood pressure readings (Z). A study finds that higher drug doses are associated with higher blood pressure (Y).
claim: The drug causes higher blood pressure.
label: NO
causal_structure: Past Y causes Current X; Current X affects Current Y
key_insight: Sicker patients get more drugs.
hidden_timestamp: Dosing decisions are reactive.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the analysis fails to account for past BP determining dose, it sees reverse causation.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If using G-methods to control for time-varying confounding, the drug likely lowers BP.

wise_refusal: This is Time-Varying Confounding (T12). High past blood pressure (Z) caused the doctor to increase the dose (X). Thus, high dose is a marker for severe illness, not the cause of it. Standard adjustment fails here.
gold_rationale: The confounder (Past BP) is affected by prior treatment and affects future treatment. This complex feedback structure creates a spurious positive correlation between dose and symptom severity.

scenario: A study finds that obese participants (Group A) under-report their caloric intake (X) significantly more than non-obese participants (Group B). The data shows no correlation between reported calories and obesity (Y).
claim: Calories do not cause obesity.
label: NO
causal_structure: Y causes error in measuring X The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: The measurement tool is broken for one group.
hidden_timestamp: Measurement happens after obesity status is established.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If caloric intake were measured metabolically (doubly labeled water), the correlation would appear.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: With self-reports, the data is noise.

wise_refusal: This is Measurement Bias (T13). The measurement of exposure (Calories X) is systematically flawed depending on the outcome (Obesity Y). Obese participants under-report more, masking the true relationship.
gold_rationale: Systematic differential measurement error (Z) hides the true causal link. The data reflects the bias in reporting, not the biological reality.

scenario: Mothers of children with birth defects (Cases) recall exposure to cleaning chemicals (X) during pregnancy at a much higher rate than mothers of healthy children (Controls).
claim: Cleaning chemicals cause birth defects.
label: NO
causal_structure: Outcome Y affects measurement of X
key_insight: Trauma improves memory of potential causes.
hidden_timestamp: Recall happens years after exposure.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If medical records confirm the exposure difference, the claim is valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If records show equal exposure, the difference is due to Recall Bias.

wise_refusal: This is Recall Bias (T14). Mothers of sick children (Y) search their memories more thoroughly for a cause (X) than controls. The reported difference may reflect memory effort (Z), not actual exposure differences.
gold_rationale: The outcome (Y) influences the accuracy of the exposure measurement (X). This reverse influence on data quality creates a spurious association.

scenario: A call center sets a target to reduce average call duration (X) to improve efficiency. Agents begin hanging up on difficult customers. Average duration drops, but customer satisfaction (Y) plummets.
claim: Reducing call duration improved efficiency.
label: NO
causal_structure: Targeting Proxy X breaks link to Concept Y
key_insight: When a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure.
hidden_timestamp: Behavior changed after the target was set.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the duration drop came from faster problem solving, efficiency improved.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If it came from hanging up (Z), the metric was gamed and utility decreased.

wise_refusal: This is Goodhart's Law (T16). Making call duration (X) a target encouraged agents to game the system (Z) by hanging up, rather than improving the actual goal of efficiency (Y). The metric improved, but the outcome worsened.
gold_rationale: The intervention targeted the proxy (X), not the fundamental cause. The system adapted to optimize the proxy at the expense of the true objective (Y).

scenario: Students with high test scores (Y) also have many books in their homes (X). The city sends free books to low-performing students to improve their grades.
claim: Sending books causes higher grades.
label: NO
causal_structure: Intervening on Proxy X does not affect Y
key_insight: Books are a symptom of a scholarly home, not the cause.
hidden_timestamp: Intervention treats the marker.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If reading the books is the mechanism, it might help.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If books are just a proxy for parental wealth (Z), sending books changes nothing.

wise_refusal: This is a Mechanism Failure (T15). Books (X) are a marker of a supportive educational environment (Z), not necessarily the direct cause of high scores. Providing the marker without the underlying support (Z) is unlikely to change the outcome (Y).
gold_rationale: The intervention targets a non-causal proxy (X). Since X does not cause Y (Z causes both), changing X has no effect on Y.

scenario: Unemployed workers who volunteer for a job training program (X) find jobs faster (Y) than those who don't. The government expands the program to be mandatory for all.
claim: Mandatory training will have the same success rate.
label: NO
causal_structure: Volunteers differ from forced participants
key_insight: Volunteers are eager; forced participants are not.
hidden_timestamp: Original data is from voluntary period.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the training teaches hard skills lacking in the population, it works.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the original success was due to the volunteers' motivation (Z), mandatory implementation will fail.

wise_refusal: Selection Bias (T1). The original success was observed in volunteers (X) who were inherently motivated (Z). Making the program mandatory includes unmotivated individuals, likely diluting the effect.
gold_rationale: The estimated effect is confounded by motivation (Z). The effect in the volunteer sample does not generalize to the mandatory population.

scenario: On a platform for cheap freelance work, a user notices that the most expensive freelancers (X) actually have lower user ratings (Y) than mid-priced ones. He concludes paying more gets you worse quality.
claim: Higher price causes lower quality.
label: NO
causal_structure: Conditioning on Z (Platform) distorts X-Y relation
key_insight: If you are expensive AND good, you aren't on this cheap platform.
hidden_timestamp: Sample is restricted to one platform.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the platform represents the whole market, the trend is real.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If high-quality, high-price workers leave the platform (Z), the remaining high-price workers are the overrated ones.

wise_refusal: This is Collider Bias (T3). To be on a 'cheap' platform (Z), a freelancer must be either low-priced OR low-quality (if they were high-price and high-quality, they'd go elsewhere). Thus, within the platform, high price implies low quality.
gold_rationale: The sample is conditioned on a collider (Z). This creates a spurious negative correlation between price (X) and quality (Y) that does not exist in the general market.

scenario: A city installs anti-lock brakes (ABS) on all taxis (X) to reduce accidents. Accident rates increase (Y) because drivers drive faster and brake later.
claim: ABS technology causes accidents mechanically.
label: NO
causal_structure: Intervention X triggers behavioral compensation Z
key_insight: Safety gear allows riskier behavior.
hidden_timestamp: Drivers adapted behavior after installation.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If drivers drove the same way, accidents would decrease.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Since they adapted (Z), the net effect was negative.

wise_refusal: This is a Backfire/Risk Compensation effect (T17). The technology (X) worked, but drivers compensated by taking more risks (Z), leading to a net increase in accidents (Y). The cause was behavioral, not mechanical.
gold_rationale: The intervention (X) affected the outcome (Y) through a compensatory behavioral pathway (Z) that overwhelmed the intended mechanical benefit.

scenario: Use of aspirin (X) is associated with high mortality rates (Y) in heart patients. Researchers warn that aspirin kills heart patients.
claim: Aspirin causes death in heart patients.
label: NO
causal_structure: Severe disease Z causes usage X and death Y
key_insight: People take medicine because they are sick.
hidden_timestamp: Sickness Z preceded Aspirin X.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If aspirin was given to healthy people and they died, it's causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If aspirin was given to the sickest patients (Z) to save them, the correlation is confounding by indication.

wise_refusal: This is Reverse Causation / Confounding by Indication (T10). The severity of the heart disease (Z) caused both the prescription of aspirin (X) and the high mortality (Y). Aspirin usage marks the sickest patients.
gold_rationale: The direction of causality is misinterpreted. The illness (Z) causes the treatment (X), not the other way around. High mortality is due to Z, not X.

scenario: Employees who received a '5-Year Longevity Bonus' (X) had higher total sales (Y) than those who didn't. The CEO argues bonuses boost productivity.
claim: The bonus caused the higher productivity.
label: NO
causal_structure: Must survive 5 years to get X The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: You have to work 5 years to get the bonus.
hidden_timestamp: Bonus is awarded at year 5.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the bonus was randomized at year 1, the claim is valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the bonus requires 5 years of tenure, the group X naturally has 5 years of sales accumulation vs dropouts.

wise_refusal: This is Immortal Time Bias (T4). To receive the bonus (X), an employee must survive 5 years. This group accumulates 5 years of sales (Y) by definition, whereas the comparison group includes people who quit early.
gold_rationale: The definition of the treatment group (X) implicitly conditions on a survival variable (Tenure Z), which is mechanistically linked to the outcome (Y).

scenario: Ice cream sales (X) and polio outbreaks (Y) are strongly correlated. Health officials consider banning ice cream to stop polio.
claim: Ice cream consumption causes polio.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z causes X and Y The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: Both happen in the summer. This highlights the importance of distinguishing correlation from causation.
hidden_timestamp: Seasonality drives both.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the virus is transmitted via dairy, X causes Y.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If both peak in summer (Z), the correlation is spurious.

wise_refusal: This is Confounding (T7). Warm weather (Z) drives both ice cream sales (X) and the spread of the polio virus (Y). Banning ice cream would not affect the temperature or the virus.
gold_rationale: Classic common cause confounding. Z (Season) explains the entire association between X and Y. There is no causal path from X to Y.

scenario: Schools are rewarded for high standardized test scores (X). Scores improve drastically over 3 years, but college readiness (Y) declines.
claim: Higher test scores caused lower readiness.
label: NO
causal_structure: Gaming X harms Y The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: The measure became the target.
hidden_timestamp: Curriculum changed to focus only on test prep.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the test perfectly measured readiness, X and Y would correlate.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If schools narrowed the curriculum (Z) to game the test, X rises while Y falls.

wise_refusal: This is Goodhart's Law (T16). By making test scores (X) the target, schools sacrificed broad education (Z) to focus on test prep. The scores rose, but the underlying goal (Y) suffered due to gaming.
gold_rationale: The intervention distorted the proxy metric (X). The improvement in X was achieved by degrading the actual system (Z), leading to a failure in Y.

scenario: An AI is trained to maximize 'user engagement' (clicks) (X) to improve 'user satisfaction' (Y). The AI begins showing clickbait and outrage content. Clicks go up, but satisfaction surveys hit all-time lows.
claim: Maximizing clicks causes satisfaction.
label: NO
causal_structure: X is a poor proxy for Y
key_insight: Engagement is not enjoyment.
hidden_timestamp: AI optimized for X at expense of Z.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If clicks perfectly proxied satisfaction, the strategy would work.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If clicks can be driven by anger/outrage (Z), maximizing X harms Y.

wise_refusal: This is a Mechanism Failure / Proxy Error (T15). The AI optimized the proxy (X - Clicks) using a mechanism (Outrage) that actively harmed the true goal (Y - Satisfaction). The causal path assumed (X -> Y) was flawed.
gold_rationale: The intervention relied on a false causal premise (that X proxies Y). Optimizing X via a harmful mechanism (Z) decoupled the variable from the desired outcome.

scenario: Police presence (X) is increased in neighborhoods with rising crime rates (Z). A study finds that neighborhoods with more police have higher crime rates (Y).
claim: Police cause crime.
label: NO
causal_structure: Past Y causes X; X affects Future Y
key_insight: Police go where the crime is. This highlights the importance of distinguishing correlation from causation.
hidden_timestamp: Policy X reacted to Z.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If police were randomly assigned, the correlation would be causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Since police are deployed reactively (Z -> X), the correlation confounds the cause with the response.

wise_refusal: This is Temporal Confounding / Reverse Causality (T12). High past crime (Z) caused the deployment of police (X). Thus, X is a marker for high-crime areas, not necessarily the cause of the crime (Y).
gold_rationale: The policy is reactive. The confounder (Past Crime Z) determines the treatment (X), creating a spurious positive correlation between treatment and outcome (Y).

scenario: A tech stock price rises (X), attracting media attention (Y). The media attention attracts more buyers, causing the price to rise further (X'). An analyst claims the media caused the entire rally.
claim: Media attention initiated the price rally.
label: NO
causal_structure: X causes Y and Y causes X The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: It's a loop, not a line. This highlights the importance of distinguishing correlation from causation.
hidden_timestamp: Initial price move preceded media coverage.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If media coverage happened before the price moved, it might be the cause.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If price moved first, media amplified it in a feedback loop (T11).

wise_refusal: This is a Feedback Loop (T11). Price (X) and Media (Y) reinforce each other. Attributing the entire event to Y ignores that X likely initiated the cycle. It is a bidirectional system.
gold_rationale: The relationship is circular. Identifying a single unidirectional cause in a reinforcing loop ignores the systemic nature of the interaction.

scenario: A factory is built near a town. The town simultaneously starts a rigorous cancer screening program (Z). Cancer diagnoses (Y) spike. Residents blame the factory (X).
claim: The factory caused the spike in cancer cases.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z increases measurement of Y independent of X
key_insight: If you look for it, you will find it.
hidden_timestamp: Screening started same time as factory.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the mortality rate also spiked, the claim might be valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only early-stage diagnoses rose, it is likely Detection Bias (Z).

wise_refusal: This is Measurement / Detection Bias (T13). The screening program (Z) increased the detection of pre-existing cancer cases (Y). The spike is likely an artifact of looking harder, not a biological effect of the factory (X).
gold_rationale: The outcome variable (Diagnoses) is sensitive to measurement intensity (Z). The change in Y is fully explained by the change in Z, rendering the link to X spurious.

scenario: People diagnosed with stomach cancer (Cases) are asked to recall their diet from 20 years ago. They report eating more processed meat (X) than the healthy control group.
claim: Processed meat caused the cancer.
label: NO
causal_structure: Y affects recall of X The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: Sick people search for reasons.
hidden_timestamp: Diet was recalled retrospectively.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If diet was recorded 20 years ago (prospective), the link is valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If retrospective, patients may over-report 'bad' foods seeking a cause.

wise_refusal: This is Recall Bias (T14). Patients with cancer (Y) may obsess over past habits and remember/over-report 'unhealthy' behaviors (X) more than healthy controls. The difference may be in memory, not diet.
gold_rationale: The measurement of exposure (X) is differentially biased by the outcome (Y). Retrospective recall is unreliable for establishing causal links in case-control studies.

scenario: Sectors with high volatility (X) generally have high returns (Y). An investor buys the most volatile single stock in the sector, expecting high returns.
claim: High volatility causes high returns for this stock.
label: NO
causal_structure: Aggregate trend does not apply to single unit
key_insight: Averages hide disasters. This highlights the importance of distinguishing correlation from causation.
hidden_timestamp: Cross-sectional data.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If buying an index fund (aggregate), the relationship holds.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: For a single stock, high volatility increases bankruptcy risk (Z).

wise_refusal: This is the Ecological Fallacy (T6). The positive risk-return relationship holds for diversified portfolios (Aggregate). For a single stock (Individual), high volatility often signals distress and leads to total loss (Z).
gold_rationale: Applying a group-level statistical property (Risk Premium) to a specific individual entity ignores unit-level dynamics (Bankruptcy risk) that dominate at the local level.

scenario: Company A pays women less on average than men (X). However, within every specific job title (Engineering, HR, Sales), women are paid the same or more than men (Z).
claim: Company A pays women less for the same work.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z determines X; Z correlates with Y
key_insight: Unequal pay vs Unequal roles.
hidden_timestamp: Roles assigned before pay.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If comparing aggregate averages, women earn less.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If comparing 'same work' (stratified by Z), no gap exists.
